Review Title: Rubbish piled up all along the beach
Review Text: Disgusting rubbish piled up all along this small beach and the water was full of it too ... avoid it and  travel further down the coast for a less polluted beach experience

Review Title: Being lonely is definitely not here.
Review Text: From Unawatuna, this beach can be reached either by tuk-tuk or on foot. When you walk through the jungle, you comfort yourself with the hope of being on something so desolate and feeling like Robinson Crusoe. However, such an obvious thought will not only visit you, and upon arrival you will find that there are fewer people here than on the beach of Unawatuna, but their concentration is significantly higher, as the beach is small and narrow. Significantly less than in Unawatuna. There are, you might say, two. So behind the loneliness, definitely not here! But of course, there are benefits. The wave here to the beach is tangent, so it's quiet. Plus, of course, the mangrove jungle adjacent to the beach creates a different atmosphere. Overall, a great addition to Unawatuna Beach, though not an alternative.

Jungle Beach in Sri Lanka is a hidden, serene cove near Unawatuna, surrounded by lush forest and calm turquoise water. It’s perfect for swimming, snorkelling, and relaxing away from crowds. The soft sand, coral patches, and peaceful atmosphere make it a favourite spot for travellers seeking nature and quiet coastal beauty.

Jungle Beach Ahungalla is a serene tropical hideaway that perfectly blends nature and comfort. Nestled between lush greenery and the ocean, it offers a peaceful escape from the crowds while still being close to Ahungalla’s beautiful beaches. The rooms are spacious, clean, and designed with a rustic, eco-friendly charm that fits the jungle setting.
Jungle beach I think it’s one of the best beaches in sirlanka we went there and we really liked the water and sand and everything was good but there is a lot of people
Lots of plastic waste, sunbeds free, but one drink per person. Sweep only the beach in front of the loungers, otherwise dirty

The calm, clear waters make it ideal for both novice and seasoned swimmers. Underwater, you’ll encounter colorful reef fish, crabs, eels, and occasionally turtles—even if parts of the reef aren’t as vibrant anymore Some boat tours and snorkeling trips are available too

Review Title: Beautiful (and busy) small beach with fun waves
Review Text: This beach is in a beautiful setting, surrounded by lush greenery with a beautiful peace pagoda at the top of the path. On the day we visited there was very little sand and the beach was very crowded. The sea is quite rough here so you need to be careful not to swim out too far because of the strong currents, but we loved having fun in the waves. As with lots of other places in Sri Lanka, unfortunately it’s not the cleanest with noticeable plastic rubbish around.
Sea full of plastic 😢 The Road to jungle beach is filled with rubbish. More plastic than trees, which all ends up in the sea

If you are looking for a truly special beach experience near Unawatuna, this beach promises both a secluded atmosphere and an adventurous approach. It isn’t easy to reach, the most practical way is by tuk tuk, but even then, a steep, winding path leads you down through jungle. The Jungle Beach is a small, picturesque section of coast, where usually there are only a few people, there are no long promenades or big crowds here. Sometimes, loud barking or noisier tourists disturb the peace, but the beach is still popular for its gentle stray dogs who love to lie beside sunbathers, and the monkeys jumping along the path. There are one or two simple cafés on the beach, where you quickly get your refreshments and can also rent a sunbed.

Overpriced sun loungers. Avoid or bargain harder than me lol. Lots of plastic debris in the sea. Nice enough but overall the plastic trash put me off. It’s actually cleaner than a lot of beaches in SL that we’ve seen so make of that what you will.

Due to the local mafia knock-knock, your tucker will drop you well before entering the location 0.5-1 km). There's a lot of greenery, and really it's like the jungle, you can find monkeys and a lot of natives that frolic in the lagoon on the cramped, because of the people, boats and chaiselongs, beach. We'll have to go back for the road, in a local Rosario Agro three-wheeler.

In this climate with this heat, unbelievably you're not allowed to take your own drinking water or electrolyte water. They check your bags at reception and are not allowed to take any drinks or snacks inside the premises. Totally bizarre… I arrived early and the security man wasn't there, a lady checked my bag, I thought she was just checking for alcohol which might've made sense, I don't drink alcohol. So luckily my first and only visit(I would never go back to a premises with incredibly unhealthy rules like this) I did have my own sports water bottles with me. However knowing as having been a little bit sick recently I need to drink quite a few litres of water per day at the moment, asked for a 1 L of water to mix my electrolytes sachet… They sell only fancy 650 mL glass bottles of water. At extortionate prices I might add. They said it was because their policy was no plastic, it's because they want to charge extortionate prices. Totally agree with cutting down on plastic, and there are ways… but can not their policy of jeopardising peoples hydration health. It isn't a 'swimming pool' per se, if you are looking for a fitness swim this is not the right place it's a play pool, and the establishment is for drinking and partying only. Nothing wrong with that by the way I'm just stating in case others are expecting to go there and have a good swim… You can't. Beautiful setting, lovely beach stunning sea, actually quite nice stuff ... but the whole experience spoilt by lack of care and consideration of health.
I guess this beach once was beautiful, but it definitely isn’t anymore. Dirty and full of worn-out sunbeds.
We had higher expectations on this beach. Lots of people and mostly Russians. We chose to leave immediately and find a cozier beach in Unawatuna.

Actually, this beach has everything a "dream beach" would need. Unfortunately, it is quite crowded, the loungers dirty and broken and there is an incredible amount of garbage lying around. It's such a shame. There are also no toilets...
The beach is like a beach, a lot of people on top of each other, a lot of locals. It's not clear why we ended up going there on purpose, we stayed there for an hour and left, nothing special.

We were there at the beginning of February during the week and arrived after the 10 min. Descent to Jungle Beach immediately reversed and walked up again. The beach was completely crowded and packed with beach chairs and restaurants. The view from the beach is not nice either. We like it more idyllic and quiet!
Finaly is a beach where I can swim!Not waves!Clear wather!Nice walking down!Not croweded,only some people,really like a lot!

Just a really beautiful place, definitely worth the visit. The Tuk Tuk drivers will not take you up the hill to the beach unless they are the local drivers - so it makes it a bit difficult to get to. But it is worth the effort. The beach has plenty of tourists and locals and you can take tours from the beach as well. There are restaurants and places to buy drinks etc at the beaches. They are small beautiful beaches and swimming in the ocean here is good for all ages. It is ok for snorkelling but no coral, there are a fair few fish. Potentially the snorkelling tours are better. The Japanese Peace Temple is just above the beach and worth a side trip for a quick visit - ignore the pushy caretaker.

Nice beach. Diverse their holidays at the resort. There were waves on the turtle beach and we went to this one. We took a tuk-tuk for 650 rupees. We met monkeys on the way down to the beach. There are two cafes with sun loungers on the beach. We're set up on blue deckchairs. Freshies were ordered, brought in very quickly. Waves on the beach were minimal. During the lunch we ordered at the same cafe began to descend en masse on the lower branches of the monkey. It was pretty interesting. After lunch, the weather started to deteriorate, a little rain came and waves started to rise. Towards the end of the evening, huge black clouds began to move to the left, thunder rattled and lightning shone. Everyone went home en masse. Back to Unawatuna Beach, we were taken by the cafe guys on a Rs 10,000 boat. It was very exciting and interesting to sail the waves in a motorboat. Had a great time.

Were on this beach, the descent is very steep, through the forest. The beach is clean relatively, the water is clear, there are practically no waves, there is a cafe, sun loungers, at the end of the beach there are many monkeys, you can feed, but they are better off taking food with them. We went there with a local guide, named Eranda, we met on the street, he drives a knock knock, so he and I started rolling all over the beaches. Never been late, never failed, honest and decent, I recommend. We were with him at many locations around the place, and he also took us shopping in Gali, went everywhere with us and tried to help us as much as possible. Very nice to talk to. Highly recommended if you are in unawatun . Number below , contact it will help +94 76 630 9441

Relaxed in Hikaduva and decided to change the location a little, remembered Jangle beach, which was well spoken of by acquaintances, took a knock-knock and got to this "wonderful" place, of course I will immediately say that our mistake was to go there on a weekend, so this place is in demand from the local population, so instead of joining nature got the local Gelendzhik , the people were well very many we did not even try swimming. The place itself without people might be called interesting, but the amount of garbage does not allow it. The only plus is a couple of picturesque spots on the way to the beach.

It consists of a small (closer to Unawatuna) and a large beach (towards Halle), separated by a rocky shore near which constantly swim with masks, and on the very shore on huge sharp-angle boulders climb both ways tourists. The small beach through is too crowded, because it is preferred for swimming, it has no coral reefs (as on the big one), no waves and a very smooth entrance, which is suitable for children. The large beach is much wider and sparsely populated, the beach is just as beautiful and you can lie in the shade of trees. Monkeys at every turn - bring bananas and get plenty of close-range shots.

Make sure you take the route with the stairs down to the beach! We took the shortcut there and that was a mistake-quite slippery and unpleasant. The beach was lovely but some plastic bottles and unfortunately noise pollution from barking dog and some tourists who don’t respect others - vaping and listening to their videos loudly. Nice for a swim and some monkeys around but would rate this beach too highly.

Beach is good. It’s a five minute walk down hill through a jungle.  There are no public toilets or changing rooms at the beach. I would recommend  not to litter and take it back to keep the place pristine. If you need to change and have shower a private resident  is providing for a small fee. Shower 100 rupees Toilet.   50 rupees

We walked from Unawatuna. The road is not very well kept, and I thought it was going to be nicer, more in the jungle. Between the first beach and the other 2 there is a path of large stones, not suitable for little balance. I preferred to swim. And the smallest one, the last one, that doesn't have hammocks... Lovely. White sand, fine, water that changes color, and without much current. You have time, go.

This is the worst place in Sri Lanka. Don't even think about going in there. Terrible road to go down to the beach., Mountains of garbage everywhere on the road and in the sea. People who write positive reviews about this beach, are you even normal? Do you also live in mud and garbage at home?

I would like to express my opinion on the famous Sri Lankan Jungle beach. Of all the popular and beautiful things, only monkeys.  The ocean looks like a swamp in a village, green, floating around you in mud, garbage, bags, etc. People are lying rough on top of each other. There are locker rooms, but no floors or doors. There is also a small cafe with the service of providing a sunbed, As there are prices and taste I can't say, did not come in.  Otherwise, I didn't like it. From the hotels that are nearby, it is a long way to the beach, as they write on rocks and sandbags. According to the campers there, they go to the central beach of unavatuna, a trip to tuk tuk there costs 1,000 rupees, because the road is mountainous. In general, I do not advise, to come swimming I would not, but live, especially.Be careful who plans to get to the kuk tuk you are likely to be brought to the wrong place.There is another place with the same name, but there is purely a restaurant “blue white” to which the same descent.

I DO NOT RECOMMEND COMING TO THIS BEACH AT ALL, succinct, full of plastic and disgusting, the bathroom is disgusting you bathe among plastic. SRI lanka has much better beaches. I don't put a zero on it because you can't

Really wanted to watch the famous Jungle Beach. They came to the beach on a tuk tuk. Then a little way down the path and there it is - the beach. The beach has a cafe with sunbeds, no big waves, people swimming. But we didn't go swimming. Very dirty, garbage everywhere, coconut scraps, tree branches. The beach is not looked after at all. Polluting nature, it's all messed up. Near Jungle Beach many monkeys fed them bananas.Back went on foot to Unawatuna to the beach through the forest along a path. You can't get lost, there are signs everywhere. If you turn right and go down the path to the sea, you'll have a small waterfall. And they saw iguanas, peacocks on the way. It took 30 minutes. If the Lankans don't take care of the beach, then let's start with ourselves and not throw rubbish underfoot. Let's not pollute nature, we all live on this little planet!

Really disappointing we walked in the jungle surrounded by plastic and when we finally reach the beach, unloaded open waste everywhere that the current brings back. We talk to the owner of the restaurant who tells us that this is very rare and that it comes from the coast and that they are picking up. We find it very sad that such a beautiful piece of paradise and such a beautiful country like Sri Lanka is buried everywhere by garbage. This is the big black spot of our trip with stray dogs covered in fleas...

We visited Jungle Beach in early September, during the off-season. Initially, we were hesitant because we had read on TripAdvisor that the beach could be overcrowded and littered with garbage. However, our experience was quite the opposite. The beach was clean, the water was calm and perfect for swimming, and we practically had the place to ourselves. The beach bar was closed, which added to the tranquility. Jungle Beach is fairly small, so I can imagine it being quite crowded during the high season. The walk to the beach is about 10 minutes downhill from the car or tuk-tuk park, and it’s important to note that the beach is not wheelchair accessible.

Jungle Beach would be very pretty if it wasn't for the huge amount of rubbish everywhere. It's all we could focus on. Piles of it under the trees at the back of the beach, scattered through the rocks and in the water, so sad to see such a beautiful place spoiled by careless people who don't look after the environment.
A small, nice beach in the south with clean water. There is a bar nearby, and it's possible to walk there in about 5 minutes from the car park.

Beach not very clean, and especially we had all our things stolen (passports, CB, telephone), apparently it is regular according to the locals, if we had known this before... A real struggle to get back to France

We booked a Pension nearby following the many positive reviews posted about it. What a disappointment, the beach is beautiful but the water is extremely dirty, polluted by many plastic waste on the surface and in depth. We who went snorkeling, forget your mask, it won't help you except contemplate the waste.

We were reluctant to visit as had read a few reviews about all the rubbish on the beach - this was not the case when we visited - it was clean  and a nice spot to swim. There is a cafe at the beach but it seemed they were packing it up  to close for the pending wet season. Staff at the beach cafe were friendly and drinks and snacks were available. Water was calm  for swimming but we did observe a young boy who couldn’t swim get into difficulty and his father jump in fully dressed to save him. Took a tuk tuk from Galle Fort for 500LKR but the return trip was 1500LKR . There will be a few drivers waiting for your return fare. Happy we visited Jungle Beach despite some of the negative reviews.

We've visited this beach 3x during our stay. Visiting the peace pagoda and having a swim early am is great!  Sadly there was alot of rubbish in the ocean (like many spots)and on the beach today, we did our best to clean up,esp rubbish in the sea. Wish people would care for these special places a little more. great spot for sandcastles!

Very nice beach and beautiful view. There are two small beaches next to each other. On both you will find wooden loungers and a restaurant. The food was good and the price was reasonable. Unfortunately, there is garbage everywhere and a lot of garbage is also washed up, which allows you to swim in the water between garbage.
Small beach that is quite dirty. Too much trach around. Nice people that works there. Not much waves that can be good. Had no walk down from the road  for 15min On our way back we saw monkeys.

Pretty beach less crowded with tourists Short walk through the jungle before tasting the clear water and the ambient calm Meals with your feet in the water Crystal clear water without waves if you travel with children On arrival you will be sized up by a few monkeys and their babies
Too many uneducated tourists, the sea is dirty and cloudy. Coral reefs polluted.Very  few fishes.Certainly was still beautiful some years ago
Nice beach but very crowded sins many people are free from work on Saturday. We saw some fishes :) boats picked up tourist with boats.
Very beautiful beach, difficult and dirty access. Renting deckchairs is not obligatory. A little touristy and very Russian. To discover

Idyllic beach with free sunbeds and brollies if you buy a drink or eat at the cafe. There is a row of coral pieces to walk through between the sand of the beach and the sand in the sea but is fine if you tread cautiously. We had so much fun swimming and bouncing in the sea. There are a few beautiful fish to see snorkeling however the coral is dull and for us, it wasn't worth snorkeling more than once. The huge benefit to a fifty something lady is a clean, nice smelling and flushing toilet, although I recommend bringing tissues and the torch on your phone as there is no light. It can get quite busy so we always went in the morning. Best to take a tuk tuk to the jungle beach path unless you are very fit as the road is steep and endlessly uphill...even the tuk tuks struggle... The path to jungle beach is full of ups and downs, twists and turns, with some slippery places...watch out for over hanging branches as I clonked my head! Not for those with limited mobility/balance. We visited 3 times and far preferred it to the more touristy/hotel-laden Unawatuna beach.

If you want to go to Sri Lanka with children, then choose this place - here the ocean is calmer, the infrastructure is developed, there is a choice of food to suit your taste and there are more opportunities to relax.

It probably was a beautiful beach once but it is now crowded with people and dirty. There’s not even a spot to sit and even less a spot to swim. We went there on a weekend so there were many locals in addition to the tourists and it was fully packed.

Loved our stay here. The hotel has  lovely rooms that look out over the sea. From the roof terrace you can see amazing sunsets. A fairly stiff uneven walk of 10 minutes take you down to a paradise beach that is safe and so beautiful. The owners son is a qualified life guard and invited me to go snorkelling with him around the headland. It was an unforgettable experience and I’m so grateful for the kindness he showed to my wife and I. Nothing was too much trouble. If you like nature you’ll love Jungle Beach.

Pretty clean beach where it is possible to rent deckchairs. A few shops offer boat excursions, catering and fruit juices or others. Access via a small, short, stony path but relatively easy even in flip-flops but you have to be careful not to slip unfortunately in some places with waste but like in many places. Calm water
Jungle beach is silence beach place in the galle area. But don't go there in weedends. Because so many local crowd
We reached this beach with no expectations as it was recommended by a local. It was a pleasant surprise to find this pristine beach in the middle of the jungle.

We went as a family and were disappointed. The flora goes right to the beach but the beach is tiny, which is a handicap if you are female and want to wear Western Style beachwear because a lot of people will stare at you. At least we found the Japanese Peace Pagoda higher up on the hill great.

Lovely beach surrounded by natural beauty, as the name suggests you have to do a trick to get there so would not be for everyone but if you are able to make a visit. There in August so sea us quite choppy but still stunning

We spent 4 nights here as part of a road trip around Sri Lanka with our 2 teenage children (16 & 18) It has a stunning location and we swam in the sea and the pool every day. The staff were very friendly, in particular the bar tended who made us some fantastic cocktails every evening. The restaurant was beautiful and the food was very good, however, we found that the quantity was just too much. We were brought automatically brought an enormous tray of pastries (at least 4 each) yogurt, smoothies and lots of fruit. we were then expected to order from the (very extensive a la carte menu) we saw so much food left on tables. The evening menu was then 3 or 4 courses! Again we saw so much food wasted. Housekeeping came around 4 times a day to clean, change towels, turn down the beds and bring snacks!!  If you have an enormous appetite you will love it. But for us, it was a bit too much. When we asked for our beds not to be changed as we were leaving the following morning, they still changed them and made us feel a bit ridiculous to have asked. Overall though we had a great and relaxing time!
Just a little beach but hassle 2 get 2 but no monkeys as they only  come in morning and late afternoon but it was a nice swim

You can see garbage everywhere. I think it's quite normal thing in a corrupted country like Sri Lanka.(Factors to be expected). Just ignore that and try to enjoy the remaining natural beauty. (Beach near to forest - interesting) As a Local I think it's good to bring your food and essentials from outside the beach because the prices are high than usual.
I was a bit disappointed, the way down between the rocks looks pretty but needs to be careful, a lot of garbage on the way and on the beach, view is pretty basic…. Only monkeys are cool :)
nice beach i went  with my friends. it is calm and  quite  beach you have to go through  jungle to the beach its little duty but still can enjoy

A hidden gem off the coast of Sri Lanka, this bay is perfect for a dip in the ocean as there are no waves! You need to go as far as possible by vehicle down the unawatuna stretch and find parking (usually at a guest house for a nominal fee) and then it’s a short trek (approx 15 - 20 mins) from there. (We had a group of 8 kids aged 7-12). Pack a towel, change of clothes, sun block  & a picnic. No changing rooms so use a sarong / towel as a make shift cover :) There are a few stalls selling juice, snacks and water (sign posted in English and Russian!) en route but I’m not sure of prices. The achcharu at the stall down at the bay (at jungle beach) was reasonably priced. It is a famous spot so expect a crowd but also just ignore and make it your own. Some other reviewers complain about “too many locals” - this is our island and we welcome all, equally. Please don’t expect us to refrain from enjoying our own island! There were also comments that it was dirty - we didn’t witness any trash on the beach. It was a little crowded but not to the extent that we couldn’t find a spot. There were some people cooking a meal on a rock close by but it didn’t seem to bother the crowd and we didn’t see any litter. Soak in the sun and sea (while getting ready for the trek back to the vehicle - the only downside!)
terribly dirty beach with full of locals .Actually among the greatest beahes in Sri Lanka this one was the worst .the jungle road was even not the easiest to reach .doesnt worth an effort
Nice beach for a sea bath. You need to park the vehicle and move little bit . But it is worth the travel. It is getting crowded during the evening

Yet another of srilanka's filthy beaches. Take pictures but try not to look what you might be standing on This beach is popular with locals and they seem to bring a load of rubbish with them which is left on the beach and never cleaned up We visited srilanka after 10 years and the rubbish and filth everywhere is shocking. Not to mention the army of stray dogs and cats everywhere. Our view is srilanka is rapidly becoming paradise lost Is it do difficult to educate children and adults to not litter and to keep their heritage clean. Apart from that you get some good photos because the jungle touches the beach at this point.

We went to Unawatuna for three days just to end our holidays on the beach. This was beginning of August. Everyone said that it was better not to go because of the raining seasin but we saw really a little bit of rain. Unawatuna is a niice place close to Galle where we went around the fort. We went around with bikes and made nice jungle walks to the beach where we visited some hidden temples. Beautiful! There is very cosy street where are some nice restaurants and little shops. We realy liked to stay there even when it was not the season to be there for surfing or diving.
Unfortunately was this beach full of trash and not really inviting to spend much time there! 😔 really sorry to see such things happening to the nature!

This Hidden lovely beach is few kilomitrs away from Unawatuna Beach. Its Located near to  small forest and you have to walk to this hidden Beach. Its less Crowded and so senic. Sunset is amazing. There is parking facilities and better to come back from forest after 6.30 PM.

Go to the Jungle beach cafe which is the first place you pull up to at Jungle beach if getting dropped by Rick. Have a nice chicken and cheese omlette, and go and take amazing pictures on their terrace. Find Pasindu and he will take you around and ask to be introduced to his brother if you are looking to have a local legend teach you how to scuba dive. He didn't even speak a word about cost- just said pay what you feel like after. He just has a love for scuba and i got lucky. He takes his time and shows you some awesome spots as well as picks out litter from the sea along the way (amazing person) you have to meet the brothers!

Actually two beaches. The main larger Jungle beach is accessed by a steep in part, stepped in other parts, quite uneven rocky ground from the car park of the same name on the Rumasalla road. A good stretch of curving sandy beach with one beach bar with a few sunbeds. Busy on National Day with locals but quite quiet another. A very pretty cove with stunning water colour, good swimming with no waves. Around the coast, 200 metres of large rocks to clamber over is the smaller beach. Still very picturesque, just smaller. This can also be accessed from the car park on google maps next to the Peace Pagoda and has a less steep walk to it that the larger jungle beach.

The beach itself and all the greenery is magical. Getting there, not so. If you are scared of step down hill, or have trouble walking uphill, this place is not for you. When I went, there was a large number of people and unfortunately not enough space if it were to get more packed. There is a small juice bar but while watching the man make my drink, I just knew I was going to catch something. Not from him necessarily, but from the extreme lack of food hygiene. After my drink I decided to take a boat with a guy named LARA who I found out later was well known for all the wrong reasons, so beware! He is a not honest. And he has very creepy looks. He tried to charge me 20,000 LKR for less than an hour of a boat ride with no stop to see anything. With all the other beaches around Sri Lanka, I would definitely put a pass on this one.  I wouldn't consider it a MUST see.

Jungle beach is rather pleasant once you get there. Access is via a mountain path that is medium long, rocky and uneven and whilst the agile and fit can negotiate it with ease it is difficult for most of us over 70 - as I am. There is a nice shack on the beach that serves decent food at reasonable prices. The water is fresh and clear, the beach nice clean and good sand. When it came to leave I was told that the easiest route was to walk along the sea path back to Unawatuna. I was also told it would take me 5-10 min. How wrong was this info. I am sure a mountain goat could have negotiated the uneven and loose boulders far better than my arthritic sloth like agility, the boulders are rather hazardous but eventually you come to another beach. Then you have to climb back up the mountain !! Bad choice should have gone up the way I went down. However the beach is nice, what would be nice is a boat taxi running at regular intervals from Unawatuna to all these small beaches, when and if this occurs I will go back but until then leave it to those who are more agile.

Unawatuna Jungle Beach is one of the most fascinating beaches near the Galle- Unawatuna area. Small woods and beautiful trees give an eye-catching view to the beach. There are two sides which hava e proper beach in this area and you can go from one another through an adventurous small route stepping on rocks. You can take a three-wheel (tuk) or a bike to go close to this beach but the road is full of hills. If you are going on a bicycle motorbike be extremely careful with your breaks because when you come back steeps are extremely dangerous and there were a lot of accidents.

This place is incredible if you go on a Sunday, because it will be filled wiith local people who go to the sea with friends and family, so there is a charming atmosphere: many different people enjoying their incredible sea in a local way, which is the vibe I love to discover and join when I travel. The little bay is lovely, you can rent sunbeds and there is a small cafè that serves good food and cold drinks, beers and cocktails too, at honest price seen the place, that is very difficoult to reach. You will have to follow a steep path from the main road -where you leave your transport mean- down to the sea level and it’s not advisable for people who have a walking problem, beacuse it’s not paved and in some parts there are slippery passages on rocks. Coming up will be a bit heavy, but it’s surely worth the effort. Go and visit the nearby temple too, Peace Pagoda, bcause it’s very close and it’s a great place for the soul and for the landscapes you can enjoy from its first floor.
If you want to make your mind relax this is the place for it. One of the beautiful beach in the world. Longest Coral line in South Asia. Valuable jungle Sunset/ sun bath.

Not easy to access , however worth the hike ! We took a boat from Jungle beach back to Unawatuna which was also amazing view. At the bech there is a small bar serving cold drinks but nothing more than this is available

This beach requires you to walk through the jungle, hence the name, till you get to the beach. Go early so it's not too crowded, find a spot and relax. You can get food/drinks from the shack, swim, snorkel or just relax. Leave in time, going back up at sunset isn't the safest.

Jungle Beach is a small bay surrounded by jungle located in Rumassala, northwest of Unawatuna where you can enjoy a great day of sunbathing and snorkeling. Anyone with snorkeling gear can walk out and enjoy life on the reef. Things to do in Jungle Beach Walk along the beach Snorkeling Visit Japanese Peace Pagoda Swim in the sea Watch Sunset

We were expecting a little bit more out of our visit to Jungle Beach in Unuwatuna. The beach is littered with plastic and debris left behind from mindless locals and tourists alike. It is unfortunate as the beach could be beautiful if cleaned up and maintained better.
Jungle beach it’s nice and calm beach enjoy your holiday possible visit Japanese temple good place to Snorkaling

We went to Jungle beach, both of them. Recommended in loney planet. But it is so dirty, nothing to see underwater and you dont even want to go into the water because there is so much plastic and face masks and everything in the water. Also on the beach as you can see on the pictures. The wild life seems to adapt a little ( se picture)

The walk there is cool and should be combined with peace pagoda, then once there its really junglish and cool - but oh so dirty. No fun to swim with the dirt. Note that the bar on the beach is closed since covid and has been reclaimed by nature.
This is how a beach should be... just so beautiful. The only thing I don't like is that you will go there and I am greedy and want it all to myself! :-)
Jungle Beach is a nice place to have a sea bath. Clear water & less crowded, may be because we visited on a week day.
Really nice natural beach. About 20 minute walk from central Unawatuna through the forest. Less commercialised then the other beaches.
Nice beach for a sea bath. You need to park the vehicle and move little bit . But it is worth the travel.

Highly recommend for a adventure seekers. Also, it's good for a safe swimming. We went there in the afternoon as it was a sudden plan. On our way only we decided to do some outdoor cooking just for a change. Before you enter the location, you can enjoy cool king coconut from the street sellers. You can do some out door cooking in the beach with limited resources. But you have protect your belongings from Monkeys. Best time to head back is on or before 18:30Hrs as it's dark during that time. Please make sure to leave only your foot prints when you go back.

Jungle beach is a whitish sandy beach surrounded by a jungle situated at Rumassala-Galle. This was the watering point of ships of old silk route. There are foot pathways from Bonavista road to jungle beach. As this place is popular among locals better visit on a weekday.

The place is good for safe swimming, but bit rough though. Coral reef cut off the strong waves. But, standing on shore can be bit harsh for the feet since sand full of pieces of coral.  Those pieces of comes with the fast waves. Sadly at the time I visit this valuable piece of land mass has been full of plastic bottles and waste. Sri Lanka Navy and locals known to clean the entire area periodically, but it's completely visitors responsibility not to ruin the place.
Nice beach, if a bit small. Better for swimming than the surfing beaches near town. Very popular and lots of people. There's a bit of walk down to the water.
Completely overrated. View of the bay and port of Galle/factories in the distance. far better beaches in SL

This beach literally is between a jungle as shown in the picture, its very cool and relaxing but very crowded as you have to go so early if you want a good place sit, i recommend not to go in any weekend or local vacation to avoid crowding.
Nice place. This time we had the beach for ourselves. Its a bit like jungle and private.. Really liked it.

Went here as had read great TA reviews. Very crowded - Need to be there very early if you want a sun-bed. Small eatery which was ok (and who I think own the sun beds). To be honest we went to better beaches in the area. Wijaya was much nicer with lovely restaurant.
Less than expected. Nothing special. Better go to Mirissa and visit Secret beach, which is more spectacular.

It takes quite an effort to reach here. You have to pass through a path full of rocks and greenery. So wear comfortable shoes if you are planning to visit this place. The effort of reaching looks fruitful once you reach the beach. The water is crystal clear and its not much crowded.   A small beach but a must visit if you are visiting Galle or unnawatuna. We came here on a day trip from Bentota

We walked to Jungle beach from Unawatuna in about an hour, through trees,it was lovely.If you are feeling less energetic you can get a tuk tuk for about 500 rupees.The beach does get quite busy but there is a small juice bar and glass bottom boat and feeding the monkeys is fun.

just a one & half hours away from Colombo via the southern expressway, just a few kilometers away from the highway exit Pinnaduwa,  you can go with your own food or buy your food from nearby locals. mainly there are two places that provide parking space for vehicles we went to the second one that comes after the peak point in the downward which have an 'L' turn to the right. you can park vehicles, have a shower and some good food you can enjoy.

It's definitely worth the way if you are looking for that Paradise beach experience. Actually, from Unawatuna center ist just 5 min of tuktuk and 10 min walking. You can do it! There is a great view on the galle bay, clear water, the beach kisses the jungle and palmtrees all around it. Not crowded at all and locals also like to go there a lot. Stop by at Agnus Villa next door for a sunset drink on the rooftop for the most amazing view you can imagine
There is a beautiful view of the Galle city, a lovely bar, but if a boat will starts its engine to go to Galle, you cannot breathe.
This is a nice beach but not maintained properly.  The access to the beach is through a jungle. If some efforts can be taken this will become a awesome experience.

It could be a beautiful little beach with a stunning jungle walk to reach it, but once we arrived I was disappointed with how busy it was, there’s was no room to lay on the beach, large crowds of tours and extremely loud. Not peaceful as I envisioned
Smaller and more remote than the other beaches in the area  check it out for more private swim time (though avoid Saturdays when throngs of locals are likely to come).
Lots of people, lots of trash everywhere, noisy. Really not a place you want to spend your time at if you want to relax...
The jungle beach is quite crowded but the small path to walk there is very beautiful through the jungle and with some viewpoints.

The beach itself is really nice and beautiful. But there is a lot of trash everywhere! We really couldn't understand the amount of emply water bottles and plastic bags. Way down from the road to the beach is a bit difficult, I had troubles with my flipflops.

The view of the sea is fabulous. Shorts above the knee are not allowed. Although they give a piece of cloth to cover up. The drive up to this place is very nice. The various stages of Buddha’s life are also well explained and shown. A must visit place if you are around Galle.
Short walk through the jungle to get there. It was busy when we arrived but it’s worth a visit. Water is calmer here than Dalawella beach so you can to for a swim.

There are guys selling cold beer and coconuts on the shore we loved this beach.  We stand up paddled here which was awesome, then snorkeled for a bit before having a cold beer and chilling on the sand, the beach it a popular attraction and it was pretty busy.

This beach is was the dirtiest beach I’ve seen not only in Sri Lanka, but also in my all Asia trips I’ve been making for 12 years. Even the view is veautiful at beach, we couldn’t swim well because the water is rocky. Furthermore, you shoul climb too many steps to back from the beach. For me, you should skip this beach if you are into swimmable beaches.
Nice beach but heavily littered and dirty. Too crowded on a regular weekday. Expected far more. Not worth to take the climb down/up
The beach is kids friendly (opposite many other beaches nearby) but the down side is that it’s difficult to reach with small children. There are two bars at the beach.
A fantastic beach yards from the "jungle". Well worth the walk from where the Tuk Tuk driver drops you. Small beach so get there early.

Very nice beach but on the weekend is crowded with locals so looks nothing like the pictures. We walked from Unawatuna beach via the Japanese Peace Pagoda which was a nice walk and then a tuk tuk back to Unawatuna.

Jungle beach must have been a breathtaking sight a long time back. But unfortunately not anymore. After a perilous trek through the jungle and over the rock from one beach to another, it was an utter disappointment to find the second beach was to be as overcrowded and unattractive as the first. After somehow managing to get a spot for ourselves to sit on the beach and a couple of hours later, a fight broke out between some beachgoers and some beach boys. One beachgoer got himself floored by a beach thug and his buddies had to literally carry him away. It was scary and apparent that these areas were under these thugs' "jurisdiction". If i could help it, I will visit jungle beach never again.

Simply put,  a beautiful beach,  with beautiful views, nice bathing and stunning views,  with a great vibe.  Very clean,  although it takes a bit of effort to clamber down and then back up a rough pathway.

We enjoyed the challenge of walking to jungle beach and climbing over the rocks.Once there it was a nice little bay to swim and relax.There is a stall selling drinks and beer and a resturant at the top if you want something to eat.
Amazing intact beach. Problem with baby jelly stings. Nice fish appreciated when snorkeling. Coconut trees
Very nice Sri Lankan Rice & Curry. The place has fair prices and it lays just 100 meters away from the main road & beach.
The place is lesser known. But its a spectacular beach front. One restaurant. A little bit of a walk.

Yes, it’s is a bit of an adventure to reach (down a steep hill and series of stairs), but that kind of adds to the experience of ‘discovering ‘ Jungle Beach. Apply lots of bug spray for the descent. The beach itself is lovely, although you need to be wary of the sharp coral the has collected as you enter, and several large rocks not far from shore. The cove is protected, so the sea is quite calm, even as the tide comes in and churns it up a bit. The water is extremely warm and it’s relaxing just to float around and enjoy the quiet. We went on a Monday, which meant it was relatively uncrowded. It’s just sad that many people have clearly disregarded the signs to not toss garbage. You can find trash and discarded food all around the edges of the beach. Otherwise, it’s a wonderful spot.

We went her a couple of times. I liked the walk down the uneven path, through the trees with monkeys over head. Lots of locals come here and everyone smiles as you pass. Buy water at the top. Food on the beach is great, we shared a big plate of rice. Boys at the bar are fun. There is only a squat toilet and it don’t smell too good. Lo gets they charge if your not eating. The water has rocks in the middle but you can have a lovely swim here and sit in the shade. We walked round to the next beach watching the locals having fun. Then up the hill to see the temple and could here the ship wreck.
Went there after a visit to the nearby Japanese peace pagoda, but didn't stay more than 5 minutes. The beach was quite dirty, used mostly by locals. Nothing impressive...

This is located about 10 mins away from the main city. 500m away from the Peace Pagoda Rumassala. There is a jungle beach parking lot and the path leads to the beach from there. It about a 15 min trek down to the beach through the jungle. Path is sometimes tricky but there are stone stairways to make it easier. During mid day the place gets pretty crowded. The sea is clam and you can walk a long way into the sea. There is only a single cocktail bar on the beach. Near the parking lot you can drink local king coconut water etc. For those of who want to wash off the salty water there are plenty of local houses which offer a wash off for 50 bucks. From the parking lot, go towards the peace pagoda side and take the first left and you will find plenty of places.

We chose to go there because it was recommended for snorkeling.There are 2 little beaches,linked between by a pathway parallel with the seashore. It was fully crowded when we get there,at around 4 p.m.We chose the second beach and went snorkel parallel with the shore, towards the end point of the peninsula. That is were the magic happened. Although at first the water was blury, after 10 minutes of swimming we began to see real show. It's crowded with reef fish and corals. So for snorkel it's wondeful, if you know where to look. Otherwise, i wouldn't come here for the beach.
It’s a tough walk through jungle to get here but it is worth it. Nice little beach with a bar serving cocktails at a reasonable price. It’s pretty popular beach with both locals and tourists

This beach is great. The sea is lovely and calm and excellent for snorkelling.  It can get busy so best to arrive quite early. Beer, cocktails etc are available and snorkelling gear can be rented.  The neighbouring beach has sun lounges and kayaks for rent and you can order food. We preferred this one as it was less busy.
The beach is nice with a scenic setting. It is about as crowded as the Unawatuna beach. The beach quite clean.

This restaurant for me is the best in Unawatuna!!  I came here last year and thoroughly enjoyed it.  I had chicken satay to start which was awesome then belly pork.  It was just fabulous.  I finished off with creme bruleu which was just out of this world.  It was for two people so my friend helped me, but unfortunately we couldn’t finish it.  I wanted to take it back to Wales with me.  As it’s our last night in Unawatuna tonight we couldn’t finish our holiday without returning this restaurant.  Who knows I might even try something else!!    Just fab. We tend to eat early and arrive at this restaurant about 6.45 which we were told to do as it gets extremely busy after that.  I believe it closes at 10pm anyway.  Sometimes they have to close the gate early as they have so man6 customers still arriving late. Enjoy!!!    Well worth it

overcrowded by locals.. but for a reason... because its an amazing beach with crystal water... We descended to the beach from the pagoda and went back up from the other end. Recommend to go snorkeling..!  One of the highlights in my December visit for sure...!
So many people, not a secret spot anymore. Actually more locals than tourists but still only go if you want to have 'fun'. The nearby Japanese Peace Pagoda is well worth exploring.

Jungle beach was a wonderful experience. The short easy stroll down the mountain to the secluded beach. There are locals down on the beach where you can rent a day bed or get a cocktail or beer. There are quite a few monkeys to be seen as well. A very relaxing place

A 10min trek down a jungle slope (stairs) and you reach a little strip of beach. Soft sand and great waters. There are loungers on the beach that are free, and there is one small bar that serves alcohol and food. Probabky best to bring your own watee and snacks though. Definitely worth a visit! Tuk tuks at the jungle entrance ready to take you back to your hotel.

We were disappointed as we wanted to enjoy the sea and a nice beach on our last day in Sri Lanka. But we had to walk a lot in the jungle and when we finally got to the beach, it wasn't what we expected - rocks & waves. We had a child with us and we understood people recommend that beach for kids also - I still don't understand why. I recommend Wijaya instead :) The day before we got to enjoy swimming with giant turtles in Wijaya.
We came here to watch the sunset and it didn’t disappoint. Make sure you stick to the path otherwise you end up in the jungle very quickly!

It’s such a beautiful hotel. It has a lot of facilities and everything looks absolutely gorgeous!!  the breakfast is also amazing. The employees are all so nice and really friendly I want to give a special thank you to sanjeevan, Kapilan, selvi, Anuradhi. We had a really great stay and we Will defenitly visit again.

It is a beautiful hotel, with extremely nice employee's, special thanks to Sanjeevan, the nicest pool boy ever, and Kapilan & Selvi did our rooms realy good, very pretty with all the flowers on the bed. And to Anuradhi, for being an extremely nice waitress. We felt welcome and enyoid our stay a lot. Nice beach and beautiful jungle feeling around the hotel.

Very average beach more akin to a dumping ground for locals and used as a rubbish dump! Very disappointing how much rubbish is strewn about the trails down to this beach! I would be embarrassed as a local and representative of this area at the state! Once you arrive at this beach it is decidedly average compared to some beautiful spots far easily accessed.
What could be a very nice secluded beach is effectively a beach with fair amount of rubbish every where . These gold really need to establish a proper rubbish disposal and collection
We walked here and the walk was nice, but I wouldn’t go here for a day trip. Many locals love this beach, which makes it crowded.

This was a nice morning walk in the jungle to reach the beach. The sea water just tempts you to jump in the ocean as it looks too good. It's a small easy trek which anyone can walk through. Do visit if you are close by

A little 20 min walk from Unawatuna brings you to this lovely beach with green calm waters and a very quiet atmosphere. There are two beaches with shade from the trees where you can swim, do snorkeling or only chill. Perfect for families with kids. Close to Jungle Beach is the Japanese Peace Pagoda a very beautiful spot to watch the sunset.

We visited here by motorbike (it would be a good walk from Unawatuna and is bumpy road either way!) in the evening and it was lovely. The beach is small but was full of locals playing football and had a very fun vibe, and the swimming was good. Lovely views of Galle and the coastline, and also a great spot to watch the sunset if you walk up the path from where cars park. It’s near the Japanese Peace Pagoda so worth combining with a visit there.

You hv to make a short hike to descend to the beach. Not easy for the elderly. Beach itself is small but not too crowded. There are areas which hv nice sand and areas w rocks (so be careful). There are some fish not to far out amongst the rocks if u look for them.

We took a morning walk to Jungle Beach. We wore flip flops, which probably weren’t the most sensible footwear. It’s a bit of a hike downhill, with rocks and bits of shaded jungle. It was a beautiful walk and the beach itself was very pretty. There was a lot of rubbish lying around, but it was lovely to swim in the sea and cool down after getting there. There are two small shops there with cold drinks and beers. Definitely worth a visit.
Beautiful beach but takes damage on the kids and parents if you have to carry them down. Beach could also do with a cleaning as it is filthy..... the views however are fantastic
Nice beach with tricky access but need to clear rubbish problem. Great sunsets where you can sip a cold drink,”.

Jungle beach is about a 20 minute stroll from west Unawatuna. It’s not at all a secret beach! There’s signs most of the way as well as opportunistic fruit and clothes sellers. It’s a well trodden path to a small beach, that has nice shade, two beach bars and a restaurant on the east side. It has views to Galle and snorkelling opportunities. It has a good vibe and local teens like to swim and drum there.
Small beach located near Unawatuna. Easy to access with bike. Right on the corner near the main road there is bike rental with good prices.
Jungle beach ist a must! It is not easy to get there as you have to walk down through the jungle but it is worth it!

It’s quite a little hike through the jungle down a path to a beautiful little local beach where you’ll find as many locals as you will tourists😀You’re a few stand set up to sell food down at the bottom as well as drinks so you don’t necessarily have to pack anything

Overcrowded on weekends but must go place to visit !  Calm water, soft beach. Love this place! Some places rocky entrance in to the water, but wount make much of a problem. Moderate place for snorkeling. If u travel this part of the world u Must visit this place!
This is a very beautiful beach. However, beach is filled with plastics and garbage. You have to walk around 1Km to reach the beach. There is no restaurant. So you have to carry your own food.

It was a simple hike to Jungle beach. The beach itself is lovely but very busy with tourists and locals . The trail had lots of garbage , empty beer and booze bottles and cigarettes. Very disappointing!

Calm water, decent snorkelling, monkeys can be seen sometimes. We went by scooter and got charged 100 lkr and were given a dodgy fake receipt. Not the end of the world but just ruins it that locals wanna make unfair money from tourists.

Came here on morning at around 9.30am and it was really quiet with 2 tourists taking a morning swim and a couple of locals. It's definitely not the easiest beach to walk down to - loose stones in the road towards the beach pathway and then the pathway itself would be quite challenging for some. I can confirm there were around two big piles of trash (water bottles, wrappers etc), which made the beach quite unappealing to swim in.  That said, it looks to be an enclosed and small beach, so may be great for families or those looking to escape the tourists.
Close to famous Unawatuna beach and Japanese Peace Pagoda, The Jungle Beach is amazing place you need to check out. It's breathtaking view will be prettier with amazing sunset 😍😍
Nice beach, challenging walk down though, not an easy climb down for those with small children or the elderly or those with mobility issues.  Good snorkelling. Very few sun beds available.
We loved the calm tranquil  waters, the beach hut was great with fresh fish and cocktails, just the walk from The top road  was hard going in the heat , no good if you have any walking disabilities
Small dark beach would be nice if it would be less tourists. Lost of fish so great for snorkeling but looots of turists
It is a really good place to sea bath in Galle.Excellent place.Good with the family  & friend. It covers with small jungle.No big sunlight also. we enjoyed a lot. Go again soon.

Took a boat from Unawatuna to come here & snorkel The beach has a lot of people which kicks up the sands quite a lot impairing visibility. Otherwise an okay place , safe since it's a lagoon providing decent snorkelling near the rocky shoreline adjacent to the beach.
There you can see fish, many fish but during weekend it gets too crowdy. Beter go during weekday for a calm atmosphere

For me it was the most horrible beach I have ever seen in my life! And I saw a lot of beaches in Asia. Waste everywhere. And all tourists are laying next to piles of rubbish as its a normal thing. We were shocked and left immediately. Not worth to go there!

The restaurant food for breakfast and dinner outstanding truly a delight but the accommodation even though the rooms are big was a let down. We stayed in a Jungle room with twin beds that were so rickety and noisy that made sleeping difficult. Also the step down to the bathroom at night was dangerous. The beach was beautiful and pool area reasonably maintained but needed work. On the whole would have been a fabulous experience if rooms and pool been up to scratch.
Early morning was quiet, but became evermore crowded. So much garbage, so sad. Snorkelling was cool, don't do it with a tour/by boat.

Lovely beach. Was bit difficult to get there through the small mountain but it was fun. Better go with good gripping shoes. Once you are in the beach it was lovely. Can do snorkeling too. Many fish near the corals. Highly recommend visiting

We went down on a Sunday when all of the local people head to this beach and it was awesome! Busy but with a wonderful atmosphere of fun. On days other than Sunday it is much much quieter. Road to walk there from Unawatuna bay can be a little tricky but totally worth it.

Small beach near Galle, that despite some fame has nothing special. Not much sand where you can relax, the beach is not secluded and it has some boats even around it. Also it is a beach with a city view in a distance not exactly the palm tree you probably are looking for. It has the reputation of the being one of best near Galle, but nothing special. You will find better places.
Beautiful secluded beach but a little tricky to get too Steep climb down with stairs only part of the way But worth it when u get there

A small little downward hike about 10mins or so to this lovely little beach was well worth it. Got here just before midday and was lucky enough to get 2 beach beds. Wasn’t as busy thankfully as I’d expected from reading some of the reviews so had a great time. Food on offer also.. Japanese pargoda temple about 15mins up across the rocks to your left and then up a steep incline. We did it in Flip flops no problem.

Lovely spot when you get there and relatively small beach so can get crowded. Some shade near the trees to be shared with local dogs. Great for simple free snorkelling with loads of fish. Boats available if you are keener
Lovely little beach, bit of a trek to get down to from where the tutu drops you off, well worth a visit
Its a bit of a hike down and up in the heat but worth for the white sandy beach and azure water. A nice cafe on the beach. "Traditional" toilet...

It sounds ideal, but as you come around the corner and are faced with the sight of hundreds of people and sellers and boats and stalls, the idyllic image quickly shatters. It’s a 20-30 minute hot walk up and down to the beach from the streets of Unawatuna and it’s not worth it once you get there.

Just a short hike through the jungle to get there. Decent beach. A lot more coral/shells on the beach than other beaches in Sri Lanka. Beautiful, but not fun to walk on. Sad to see garbage all over the beach. Recommend heading there early to get a spot in the shade.
I saw no hips of trash described; the beach itself is rocky and small, but you may enjoy its peaceful waters. Many locals swimming.
Jungle beach is very beautiful, but it's a shame visitors and locals throw trash everywhere. There is no proper trash can and it seems that nobody cares about environmental destruction.

We coupled a visit to Jungle Beach with an early morning start at the close by Japanese Peace Pagoda. We arrived at Jungle Beach at around 8:00am and had the beach to ourselves. Beautiful sands and waters. I can however imagine this place gets very busy after around 9:00am, we left when others started to arrive.

If you want a beach to your self here you go, wake up early and either trek or catch a ride to the Jungle beach, if you reach here by 7-8am the place is your, enjoy a morning dip, with no one in sight. Romantic, peaceful and relaxing. Must Visit!

If you want to swim the waves might be an issue here but if you don’t mind large waves when you go for a dip. Jungle beach is for you. There is a small bar where you can have a beer I would not go for any food there.

We loved it here.  The beach is great for swimming as it’s very sheltered. There was no rubbish as suggested by previous posts, in fact a few chaps from the Sri Lankan Navy turned up in a boat to litter pick whilst we were there. There were a lot of local family enjoying the beach which was very nice to see. We preferred it to Unawatuna beach which reminded me of Bournemouth, but with more bars!

This is a very pretty little beach off the beaten track. It is quite popular though, not so secret nowadays. They have a juice bar doing juices, milkshakes and cocktails. Walk to the beach is through the jungle - lovely. Nice place for a swim and relax.
lovely beach .. can have fun with sea bathing and the beautiful views. can enjoy with the family and friends
Worst beach we’ve been too in Sri Lanka, plastic and rubbish floating around... rubbish on beach... not nice. We left after 10 minutes. Very disappointed, nothing like the photos

Get there early as it’s small and starts to get busy later. Gorgeous beach to enjoy a coconut on. Steep hill to get there though. Right near the Japanese peace pagoda so you can combine the trip if it’s a tuktuk ride away for you
Great little beach about 30 minute walk from Unawatuna. Did the walk in Jandals/slippers/thongs. Go very early in the morning as the crowds start coming in from 9am onwards.
Relaxing, clean and peaceful. Bit of a trek to reach but worth the rock crossing. The second beach is the better of the two.

The rubbish underfoot tarnished any natural beauty except from a landscape perspective. If you are looking for a happening party beach at the expense of nature, Jungle beach is for you. I left after a few minutes, as the volume of litter ruined my mood.
not worth it folks bit disappointed better elsewhere long walk down to beach and not much room to put towel down
Was really nice but super busy being a public holiday. Trek down is a challenge with little kids and older parents

I'm glad we went, as the monkeys in the tree were cute.  The middle of the beach had rocks, so it was best to swim either end of the bay.  It was a trek down the hill to get there and there is only one restaurant and all the sunbeds were taken so we laid on the sand.  I liked it for a change, however we only visited the once.

This is a delightful beach in its own little cove.  It is nicely sheltered and offers reasonably good snorkelling very close-by the shore.  The fact that you have to walk a bit to get here is a big plus. We came two days before Independence day, which was a Saturday, so it was probably one of the busiest days, which meant it was overcrowded.  There was also a disappointing amount of litter. I feel that if you came mid-week and it was not a major national holiday, this place would be really special.
It was worth the walk to get there - much more pleasant than the local beach which tended to be a bit dirty at low tide
Very nice jingle beach near by galle habour and also ancient fort of south c9ast of sri lanka.y9u can enjoy there very very freedom with sun,sand and sea.

Nice place, but way to beach is very difficult. No way to get there with some health problems. Water is ok for smsll kids, and adults can swim there too. Food there is tasty, and you have choices. The water was clean.
Full of people & worst of all...plastic garbage! Visitors please take your trash with you and please stop using a new plastic straw for every coconut you buy.
Great place for swimming since there aren’t waves that would make it dangerous. We went there on Sunday and there were many locals playing ball and singing.
a different beach . Many close by major attractions including Galle fort and Rumassala peace pagoda.

While the boom in tourism is great for Sri Lanka it means previously secluded or quiet places like Jungle Beach are no longer off the beaten path or a secret. When we visited there were at least 100 people in the first small beach. Also filthy with rubbish.

Lovely beach accessible by a bit of a climb down a rocky path. Little shack on the beach who have sunbeds if you buy food/drink from them. Sadly lots of litter on and around the beach and in the water. Not idyllic crystal clear water for sure which is a shame. On our visit, lots of noisy Russians who decided it was ok to play their crap Euro pop at full volume from a portable speaker. Oddly the men spend a lot of time taking photos of their wives/girlfriends in various soft porn style poses. Maybe we where unlucky but as in Thailand it is better if you can find the places the Russians haven't.
Like an undiscovered Beach! I went there to see sunset and fullmoon. So romantic and beautiful!!!!!!
It is sad, such a awesome place. Swimming with turtles, but sharing the experience with loads of plastic. Don't be a   muppet, clean your filth.

Beautiful place to visit. Walking through the jungle next to the temple walk down to the beach only sad thing about this place it was not clean too many disposed plastic :( best for nature lovers and to do snorkelling  on the way you will see monkeys 😍🐵🐒🐠🦀

The walk to this beach was full of rubbish. Distressing. The place is filthy and full of people drinking and with loud music. There is NO snorkling to be done. On leaving we decided to tale a tuk tuk and they are slmost mafia like. We eventually called a pick me car for a third of the price and the tuk tuk drivers ganged up on the driver when he arrived, stole his keys from the ignition and used a police like batton to hit him. Dont bother going here
Enjoyed a snorkel off the rocks and spent quite a lot of time watching sizeable puffer fish in action! Took my wife and daughter and felt safe as not a fast current...
one of the most beautiful beaches I've seen in my life best way to get here is a scuter take diving/snorkling masks with you because there is a good spot for diving/snorkling
Little bit to much tourists. Wouldn't go there anymore. Tiny beach. A lot of people and to many boats.

What to write about this “beautiful” place. Full of garbage and people. It is truly a jungle beach, but i do not have the urge to pay a second visit to this place. There are much nicer beaches in south coast of SL

As much as I thought it was a beautiful spot, tourists (and possibly locals) have let it down by leaving litter behind on the beach. I feel the lack of bins hasn’t helped this, but it’s still everyone’s responsibility to clean up after themselves.

Please note there are 2 jungle beaches next to each other, but the entrances are 500 m apart. The one marked on Google maps and towards the end of the road is just Jungle Beach, and the one before that is White Jungle Beach. The latter is more beautiful. There is good swimming and sunbathing on both. The white beach has a beachside bar and restaurant, while the other one also has vendors selling beer, coconuts etc. The beaches are also good for snorkelling. The left end of the white beach has good reefs with fish. The other beach has reefs on both ends with similar fish. You might get snorkels for rent from one of the vendors on the beach but recommend renting from one of the dive centers in Unawatuna.
You can walk there or take a TukTuk. A lot of local people are using this beach, and that says it all.
Full of rocks inside the see, there is  garbage everywhere... I didn't like it at all and wouldn't recommend it.
Think this beach is more for young fit people as it was a quite a trek to get there.it is aptly named as you had to go through a mini jungle to get to it.
A short ride by tuc tuc and you reach this little gorgeous beach. Calm, a restaurant snd some sun chakra.

Flat beach with calm waves..found it peaceful n could easily spend couple of hrs swimming n snorkeling in the clear water. The walking route to beach via jungle is great experience as well. Its a short walk though.

We went during the public holidays so it was so busy with lots of noise, people & trash everywhere. There was so many public buses that was taking everyone there knocking anyone & any other vehicle off the roads. The poor monkeys was eating plastic bags full of peoples trash that they all carelessly chuck aside. Disgusting seeing what could of been a beautiful spot completely ruined.

An idyllic and quiet spot about 20 minutes from Galle Fort. 500 Rupees in a Tuk Tuk. Then a 200mtr walk through lush rain forest down to  a secluded beach. Get there early to secure a wooden Deck Chair,say 9:30am. Beach bar serves cocktails, spirits and beer and some meals.

25 min by walk from Unawatuna and down the road you can meet monkeys and vaarans. The beach is 'movie-style'. No sunbeds but you can easily hide from the sun under the trees. Warm and quiet sea that is good for kids and for swimming. You can snorkle and see some fishes next to the stones of your right hands. And i strongly recommend to try mojito and pina colada with only people who serve it by the ground boat. The best in Una!

The beach is very small and while visiting we noticed a big commotion in one of the small areas. It was monkeys eating all the trash gathered on the side of the beach! There are a few small carts selling coconuts, water and juice but then there is no place to throw the trash out so it’s gathered on the side. Dalawella beach was much better, even the main Unawatuna beach is cleaner and in my opinion, nicer to stay at.

We made the mistake of getting here close to sunset. There's a 10 minute walk to through the trees to get to the beach. It's not at all lit up so make sure you have a torch of some kind on you. It can be a bit slippery and there are a lot of mosquitoes so take your repellent! The beach was nice, buzzing with locals, music, families and we enjoyed ourselves.
You can take a tuk tuk but we walked. It was super crowded and not very big. Not worth the trek at all. There are quite a few monkeys though.

For us, the place was a bit crowded. We went on a Saturday and beside tourists, a lot of local people came. But it is amazing there. You have to walk down a jungle until you reach the beach. Water was very clear, sand very clean... paradise indeed
Cannot say that I am amazed by this beach, as it is quite small and crowded. It must have been a lonely place some time ago, but surely not now.

I should have listened to what I read. I should. That is the reason for this site. Despite, I read the reviews and I plodded on, misguidedly shunning the information I had read. Scootering up the hill from the Galle Road, caught up in a fracas between the private blue coaches, belching diesel fumes, and ferocious tuk tuk drivers who seem to think they are in the cast of wacky races and far more aggressive, thankfully with each other as opposed to the fat westerner on his borrowed moped. Reaching the top, we park, we walk, down down down the litter strewn Hill, over cobbles and past other weary travelers and locals making their way back up. We arrive, and what a load of rubbish. Literally, a load of rubbish. The beach itself, I imagine could be quite nice, but yet again the human race has let itself down, and ruined a place that could be so beautiful. If you go, expect to feel sad. I did.

The beach is very unclean and trashy. There are lots of plastic in the sea and also in the beach and the jungle. I ordered bottle of coke from jungle beach bar and it was warm not cool. The beach could be nice if trash and plastic cleaned out of the beach.
The beach was too crowdy with the local people,quite a lot of stones and corals in the water so you easily get hurt your toe. Only one restaurant - the prices quite high.
A disappointing visit in which we picked our way through rubbish to reach the beach. The sea was full of plastic bags.

This "genuine jungle beach" resembled a dumping ground. A jungle road led here from Unawatuna and we were horrified how much plastic and other junk was dumped all over the sides of the path. The beach itself looked okay for swimmers but we left almost instantly upon arriving because of the bad treatment of nature. Authorities should pay this place more attention and the people visiting here should definitely take care of their junk. I felt so sad for this place and still am.
Good sandy beach protected by the bay. The local municipality needs to provide some bins to collect the plastic.There is a risk that this amazing beach could become another rubbish dump

We walked here from our accommodation in Unawatuna beach, there were helpful direction signs to assist us finding the beach. As it was a Saturday the beach was busy but not too crowded. Nice for a swim and no currents in the water

We visited this beach based on the iddylic descriptions, but we were disappointed.  Sadly, the beach is beautiful but human interference has ruined it. The path down to the beach is well maintained and even swept but the rubbish is just swept off the path into the trees. Having secured a shady spot under a beautiful tree, we were often greeted with wafts of the odour of rotting rubbish which was piled up just behind us. Beach visitors should be encouraged to clean up their litter and the businesses should also take better measures to clean up. If you want to swim, just be cautious as you enter the sea. There is a lot of sharp and broken coral and rocks so kids are likely to get a scrape or two! In such a pretty setting, we were happy to deal with this as it's nature, but disappointed by the litter - my son fished out 3 plastic bags from the shore.

Visited on a Sunday afternoon and never have I seen so much fresh litter across one beach! The beach was packed with locals enjoying the sun, but seemingly unable to clean up after themselves. It’s a 10 minute hike down the beach and not at all worth it.

The beach was lovely with lots of locals on the weekend who were nice and chatty. After seeing reviews saying the beach was dirty we were concerned but only saw one tiny bit of litter. I’d recommend getting dropped off near the beach and walking down as it’s only 5 minutes compared to the hike from Unawatuna. Be warned though as it is quite steep in places. I’d recommend going a bit earlier in the day as it started to get busy at about 2pm. Reasonably priced food and drink on the beach as well.

Its a long and arduous hike from Unawatuna, and when you get there, it's small, a bit crowded, with one stall selling drinks. It's also not very clean, with plastic bottles and rubbish all over the place
Amazing beach.way better than Unawatuna.great guys working at the bar on the beach.you can have drinks and dinner there.well worth it.tuk tuk from Una around 400 ruppies (don't pay more)

The ocean itself is nice but the surroundings let it down massively. There is rubbish everywhere and the place is kind of trashy. The crowd is largely international. If you are looking for nice ambience and a nice place to swin, better to go to Unawatuna. This is one of those examples where unorganised tourism lets the traveller and the environment down. It would not take much for the Government and locals to clean up and take care of the place, and the actual access to the place. I wouldnt recommend going here.

We need trek down to reach this beach. Quite secluded. Eye catching water color. They even have tier swing.The view is really good. The beach restaurant people annoy you at times. The beach is not that clean.

Upon reaching the parking area, visitors would need to hike down for about 10-20minutes, depending on your age and fitness level. Word of caution to families travelling with young children and the elderly, as there are some rather steep drops and slippery corners to get to the beach. Hence it is recommended to wear good shoes. The beach was a beautiful blue👍 Glimpses of tiny, transluscent fishes swimming all about the water. Plenty of shade around to set up a picnic basket. Once done dipping, shower areas and changing rooms are available at a reasonable price back at the parking area. We truly enjoyed this experience with 2 elderly ladies and 3 young children in tow and highly recommend it!
It’s a cool little place and I tucked away down a small path. There’s also a bar so you will not be thirsty here :) it’s a small beach with nice water. Very chilled vibe
Nice place to relax, good drinks, nice view (3/5) It’s a hike down from the main road where also you can find monkeys 🐒.
We opens Berger &pizza new place in bech.every day fresh see food now making bbq.cake ice cream opens soon come visit our new place thanks
Great little isolated beach over looking a big town. Nice clear water and friendly and helpful locals. Only minus was the rubbish dumped on the track down to the beach.

It’s like stepping back in time. Rustic but free sunlounges, good fun local people. This is a great beach which gets a lot of visitors from all over the world. Plus a great place to Meet friendly locals. It’s a bit of a trek up and down, so if you are in fit give it a miss. Otherwise you should give it a go.
Nice little beach hidden from the roads. You go to the top of a hill and from there you walk down through jungle to the hidden beach. There you can find a beach bar and some sun beds.

We went in the morning during the week and there were only two other people there. Was calm, secluded and beautiful. Worth the walk down and probably the nicest calmest beach we visited in Sri Lanka, Apparently it gets very busy with locals on the weekend though.

There are 2 beaches first and second(temple jungle beach). First is bigger and it is dirty (( Second is really nice, rather clean and beautiful. I recommend to visit the second one and better early in the morning, in this case, it will be great! Enjoy

Jungle Beach is nice, small and more private, with vegetation growing almost right to the sea. There is a bar and you can rent canoes or do a boat ride. It's very popular amongst locals and tourists. It's ok but under that name I would have expected something more "wild", not so crowded and with not so many activities to join... The way from the main road is long but easy, just the first part of Rumassala Road is quite steep and the last meters in the path out of stones and roots you need to watch out, but all in all is easy to get there.

We set off to a Jungle Beach and according to sign posts we have reached just that. The beach is small and there are no facilities to buy water, eat or drink on site. You can buy drinks en route or eat at the resraurant on the top before the descend to the beach. The beach itself if situated at end of the cove and it offers a perfect swim if you happen to be a little cascious of waives at open sea. When I swam a little further away took a glance of another beach, futher down - it could be as map but not sign points out the real "Jungle  Beach". One could reach it by swimming or walking alone very rocky shore or by descending down via alternative umarked path however the locals say it is rather stranuo6us and difficult walk
The beach is nice enough, bit more relaxed than the main beach. It is a bit of walk from the main beach, maybe 20min. There wasn't any good snorkelling in the immediate vicinity that we could find.
Nice for relaxing. I n my wife enjoyed on This beach. Not many people are there. I would like to go back again there for beach.
Need to do a mini hike to reach the beach downside but it's all worth it. The beach is very beautiful, untouched and serene. There are a couple of hotels on the beach side where they serve drinks
Lovely little cove & out of the way beach. Not much there if you fancy food but a lovely spot. A bit hilly too
Very popular place so even in a low season is crowded. Very dirty but maybe because of the monsoon season?
