Although a good tuk tuk ride away from main city center but worth the effort .. a short hike through the forest takes u to this small but beautiful beach with calm water .. there is one shack for coc ktails and place to have a nice swim .  Sea can be rough at Unawatuna beach so for swimming this can be a better option.. be aware no life guard and can be real isolated at times .

The beach is really nice. We had a good time with friends. Very few shops. But not very friendly for locals. Even though we brought some food from them for a really higher price, there service was really bad.

Just 7mins drive From Unawatuna beach .. this place was an absolute find.. parked our car on top of the hill.. walked down the walking trail..reached the beach.. absolutely stunning clean water.. very few people .. perfect relaxation in d wAters..

Limited shops, but it is sort of near a jungle. A few steps to get in here but nice place to visit if you are able bodied. Shady walk in, tuk tuk’s avail to take you out and I guess, we walked from the Unawatuna past the Japanese peace pagoda along the rocks to get in. A bit challenging but ok if you are steady on your feet. We all need a bit of exercise when we are on holiday.

It's secluded beach.to get to it you have to cross lot of jungle and then you come to nice beach don't worry if the trek is too much you can either take tuk tuk or drink coconut for 20 pence There is a nice buddist temple donated by japan so all in all enjoyable day I would recommend
Visited jungle beach on a recommendation from a friend and was severely disappointed there was rubbish everywhere and people urinating in the bushes it really isn't worth the hassle to get there.
Visit white jungle beach first, it is bigger and less crowded than jungle beach. Worth the walk but is small and crowded.

One of the best places to visit in Galle. Like unawatuna there are no restaurants or hotels. There is one sea food restaurant but prices are bit high compared to outside the beach. This place is crowded in weekends and people come as groups . Therefore better to visit here on weekdays. Sunset is amazing from the beach and you can see Galle city. Not far from highway entrance. Take a tuk or if you have vehicle you can go close to the beach and walk 800 meters.

This beach is vlogged about alot on YouTube, however it is incredibly small albeit alot prettyer than Unawatuna Beach but certainly nothing you won't have seen before. Not sure where the jungle is. What is the difference between the Jungle and the forest? You walk through a little vegetation but depending on your route its all pretty much man made. It's a tourist trap to be fair. Its worth a walk if you fancy a walk but doesn't live up to its drone footage or YouTube Vlogs.

I would advise visiting here midweek as at the weekend apparently it gets packed with locals and there is high volumes of litter. They do a clean up Mondays and when we went on a Tuesday it was lovely and peaceful and has a small bar where you can order some juice, lion beer and other soft drinks with a small good menu. The water is calm here so it makes it easy to go swimming.
A secluded beach in Unawatuna. Need to take a tuk tuk or a bike. The path to this is uneven. But the views from the beach is worth the walk. Try to visit early mornings to beat the heat

I had only heard great things about jungle beach so decided it was definitely worth a visit. I walked there from Unawatuna and was glad I'd read reviews on here describing how to get there because it is not really signposted until you are almost there. I enjoyed the walk and locals were helpful in pointing me in the right direction. Don't expect an easy stroll - it is quite a trek on uneven and narrow trails with large rocks. However, you may be lucky to see monitor lizards, peacocks and other animals along the way like I did. When I got to the beach I was quite disappointed - maybe it was the time of year but the water was rough and dirty, the sands were littered with rubbish and debris. My belief that I could snorkel in tranquil waters and see lots of beautiful fish was instantly killed. In the 5 mins I tried to go into the water, I got scratched quite badly by rocks you cannot see through the murky waters.  Even when I tried to go into the water further up the beach, I quickly got out again due to the amount of rubbish wrapping itself around my legs. Such a shame - but I bet the waters are calmer, clearer and the beach cleaner at high season in Summer. At least I saw a huge monitor lizard - that was really cool.

One of the few uncommon and attractive beaches in the world. Ideal for snorkeling.... an experience not to be missed. Highly popular among locals. Better to avoid weekends and public holidays as the place gets overcrowded and heavy traffic on narrow access road.
very beautiful beach, available boat rides, have to walk a little distance, strongly recommend, ....

Jungle Beach, Unawatuna - We visited having read about it in the Lonely Planet guise. Bit of a trek to get to but well worth it! Not a large place but it wasn’t crowded either when my family visited in August. Cold soft drinks sold on the beach which was a welcomed sight!
Short walk down the hill path from Rumasalla Pagoda, shady beach, waves crashing on rocks and views of Galle town. Really enjoyed walking back from there to Unawatuna beach in the evening.

Jungle Beach is really a short walk from Unawatuna (about 40-60 min) through the jungle then climb down to the beach that is secluded and overlooks Galle. First came here over 3 years ago and it felt more exciting back then as it really was like a trek in the jungle but this time, felt that Unawatuna in general and the walk to Jungle Beach was now becoming more built up and busy. The walk passes through dozens and dozens of hotels and B&B's and it is likely to be more crowded and busy once the monstrosity of a hotel is built in the Unawatuna beach! So better get here quick before it loses its charm. The positives is that because the area still belongs to the Dept of Wildlife, they have stopped or done away with the previous make-shift restaurants that were right by the beach at Jungle Beach. It seems to be more of a place where a lot of locals come in for a day/weekend trip. Since we went there on a Sunday, it was very busy. Also a tad noisy but everyone seemed to be having a good time. You can swim here too but the sea is now seems to be littered. Strangely though the walk from Unawatuna and though the jungle seemed clean and came across only a few discarded PET bottles. The climb is only slightly difficult but recommend shoes unless you are a flip-flop pro in which case you can still easily do the climb up and down unless you are unlucky to do the trek on a rainy day. Make sure to take lots of water though, as it is humid. There are a few restaurants around in the vicinity before you climb down to the beach that offers local food for good prices. We didn't have lunch there, so no idea how the food was. If you don't fancy eating after the walk, you can always a grab a bite to eat once you get to Dalewala road which has all the touristy shops/restaurants.

This secluded beach facing Galle fort is pretty nice and usually not too crowded. The water is much cleaner than in the bottom of the bay making it a nice place to swim and snorkel. If you have limited mobility you may reconsider your visit as you need to walk down (sometimes steep) on a rocky path for 5-10 minutes to access it. Food there is very expensive for what they serve but not bad.
Charming place. Unfortunately it’s kind of trashed. It’s sad that people just couldn’t care less. The walk from Unawatuna is a nice one.

I went here with some friends on a very hot day. It was full of people and it’s not a very big beach. There is a bit of a hike down to the beach so make sure that you have some good shoes. Also, the monkeys are not nice. Remember that for everywhere really. Inside the water, there is a lot of dead coral and its not the softest sand. Maybe some water shoes are your best bet for this beach.
Its really cool for visitors.best one of the best beach in sri lanka.and only one beach with jungle.amaizing.just near from unawatuna everybody shold visit there to feel it
This is really beautifull beach. The sea is not rough in January and you can swim. You can also drink good coctail

Take the time to navigate the rocky pathway down to Jungle Beach - totally worth it. The beach is clean and calm (we found maybe ten people lolling about), the water is swimmable, there's a small cafe if you need one, and it's all in all a bit of a hidden treasure.
Nice beach and quite sheltered with nice sand.  You can get by foot - good walk thru jungle and nature to get to the beach, worth doing.

We went on a poyaday and it was so crowded we didnt hv a place to park the vehicle..beach is very nice but due to the large number of people is was very noisy and full. We immediately change our plan to hv a sea bath there and went to a different beach.

We were recommended by few people to see this beach and read reviews. But when we actually went their we were slightly disappointing. There was nothing special about this beach just the possibility to take nice pictures. It's small, you can hardly swim there as there some rocks and dead corals in the water. One time is enough for this place. Just to avoid going there at the weekend as it gets very crowed the weekend specially with local people.

A beautiful beach with delightful walk through the jungle which is being spoilt by rubbish - plastic , glass etc. One visitor cut his foot so badly on a broken bottle in the water requiring hospital and stitches. Take care !

Jungle beach is a beautiful secluded beach in Galle bay. Sorrounded by palm trees and jungle, it takes a nice hike to reach it. The main problem it faces is that the sea currents bring trash from the bay and as a result jungle beach is dirty despite the efforts to burn the trash.
Small beach with a small «restaurant». We did not dare to eat there as they do not have electricity. Lots of trash in the water and the woods. Other than that; a quiet beach.
Great little beach hidden at the end of a small path through the forrest. Lots of complaints about the rubbish but there was not too much and the location more than made up for it.
Was the dirtiest beach that we have ever encountered . It was even worse than any Indonesian beaches that we have been to . Such a shame as it could be such a wonderful place.

Disappointing place as both the way thereto and the water are full of litter.... I can imagine the charm when discovered for first time but not such a natural place anymore. mihirripena is much more scenic and the unawatuna more pleasant...can be skipped without missing much..

The best part of Jungle Beach is the walk to get there - very quaint and scenic.  You are truly walking through jungle to get to the beach.  Other beaches are much nicer, beach wise, but this is an interesting and different hike if you are so inclined.  I hope that they clean it up...
It is not a good beach for family or to foreigners. Should maintain properly. It is so durty. Locate and View is Great .

We stumbled across this incredible beach by chance. It’s beautiful. Then why the 3 stars? It’s unfortunately littered with rubbish around the shoreline. We hope this is attended to as it is starting to now wash into the water. We will change our review to 5 stars should this be fixed
Not easy to access but worth the short hike for a beautiful beach, with locals instead of tourists. Lovely to see pineapple and palm trees whilst swimming too.
Had to trek through jungle with few directions to get to this beach. It started to rain as well. This beach is popular with young local Sri Lankans.

We stopped here as we were leaving Unawatuna and walked down to discover a stunning beach. It didn't take long for us to decide to walk back up to get swimming gear and we then enjoyed a good hour or two relaxing and swimming before continuing on our journey. The water was calmer than in other places along the south coast at this time of year, which made swimming much more relaxing.

The beach can be reached after a 30' min walk from Unawatuna through jungle, which is quite an experience itself. Jungle beach is a secluded place frequented mainly by locals, which makes its specific charm and authenticity. Worth a visit, especially as a counterbalance, if you are based in tourist-packed Unawatuna.
Worth a visit! Quieter than Unawatuna beach and filled with locals which made it feel very authentic and charming. The restaurant also serves delicious food!

We did the hike to jungle beach yesterday and astonished at the amount of rubbish there was scattered everywhere along the way and when we got there. We were completely disappointed by the beach and literally stayed to swim for about 15 mins then headed back to unawatuna. It's really not what it's cracked up to be but has probably been ruined over time - such a shame!
Dont bother going. There are much better beaches. Its dirty, has no appeal and therefore a waste of time.

A pretty beach a 30 - 40 minute walk from the middle of Unawatuna. Some steep hills. I think it is possible to go some of the way in a tuk tuk but you have to walk the last bit. Jungle Beach is a small pretty beach with gentle lapping waves. The only thing there is a chap selling fruit smoothies freshly made and another lady was selling cokes and other soft drinks. Nice beach to pass a bit of time on. We thought there would be some snorkelling opportunities but there wasn’t.
Jungle beach should be renamed Junk beach. The beach is completely covered in rubbish and is a disgrace. Do not waste your time going down there.
Nice beech to visit. Should be there early morning. It'll be crouded during the evening. Visit the second beech at the end.

Jungle Beach is an uncommon beach in Sri Lanka. The beach is surrounded by a (small) jungle. That is how this beach got its name at the first place. It is a part of Rumassala Sanctuary (hill). It is a beautiful and wonderful place. Jungle Beach is a relatively large area divided by rocks and the jungle. Make sure to visit all the parts of it, if you ever visit. It is a good place to have a joyful bath. But be careful in off season for sea, since it can be dangerous. Some deaths have also recorded there in off season. So best thing is to avoid bathing there in off season. Paid (private) parking facilities are available there.

We enjoyed a few hours here. It's definitely not as good as the reviews say as it's hard to get to and there isn't much beach. So check it out but it's definitely not a full day trip. Certainly don't go out of your way to see it .
Anyway who loves sun and the sand will admire this place it’s one of the safest and nicest beaches in unawatuna

This is very close to the Japanese Peace Pagoda. It is the best place to see the sea and the land outline as a great view. When you just passed 100m by walking it's the Jungle Beach. You can fish, enjoy a chilled beer while swimming, diving or snorkeling. Nature's beauty is there to entertain you very much.

We had a lovely time at this beach.  The walk down was neat with the stone steps.  Restaurant was perfect for a fish lunch and several beers.  We went during the day and in June.  We did not experience any of the harassment described by the other reviewers.  There were boys playing frisbee on the beach and my boys took part. It was really enjoyable to see the blend of cultures.
The walk down to jungle beach is awesome. Great scenery, shallows for snorkelling and swimming. No corals near the shore.enjoying the sunny afternoon.Will be a nice hangout place for an nice evening.
Just a small beach near the Galle Fort about 5km with Tuk tuk. It is hidden small beach but it is nothing very special comparing with all other beaches in Sri Lanka.
Easy to get to beach by tuk tuk not too touristy and really good to take a relaxed swim in. Nice little Spot and much cleaner then the other beaches around galle.
Small Beach with a nice view. Had to climb down to reach the beach. took about 10 minutes. The view is nice. With greeneries on both sides. Good place for a drink or two.

Great little secret tucked away. We had a good walk down to the beach. Be sure to wear suitable footwear (sneakers are fine, flip flops would be difficult). Lots of locals there playing their own instruments which was fun. I wish there was someone selling beers there though! The Jungle Beach Inn (not on beach) wasn’t open either.
I have traveled to Jungle beach twice and both times I had a great time. Best time to travel is during the evenings.

The beach was okay, (to me it wasn’t very clean comparing to other beaches ) BUT there were so many drunk people who were very annoying , especially for Foreigners. Don’t go at evening until you’ve a guidance from trusted one. It’s UNSAFE . I Saw,  a group of foreign girls were bothered by few drunk brats, who asked for a selfie And that was too much. Note- 1. skip this if you can. This is an island so you can find beautiful beaches with views rather than this 2. Locals are trying to help you for money(not all)so don’t pay for anything. If they asking for unfair fee for something, Speak against it. ( in SriLanka they think that foreigners are millionaires) 3. stay safe

Beach was okay but the way is terrible especially with children. Have to take an auto to reach to the hill than have to go for off road walk for 15 to 20 minuets to reach the beach. Auto driver's ask a lot for ride. Hanuman temple and Buddha temple are also there on the hill. It's totally a skip able place.
This stretch of the beach is quiet, looks rugged and undisturbed.   and not too appealing.   Not frequented by many tourists or locals

Such a shame. Went to check it out and the beach had spots just full of plastic and glass bottles. Also warned by the some tourists who had just been that some locals were wasted and harassing tourists by going under water and grouping them. Got to the beach to about 40 locals drinking so left. Apart from that it was a pretty beach just ashame that it was covered in trash.
Better beaches with less effort It’s quiet but there are no services on beach so I would say you are better going east towards thalpe where the beaches off the road are amazing .

I am sure this beach would have been the best beach in the whole Srilanks....But it is not now. A small trek downhill and you will reach the Jungle Beach. As you would imagine...you will be in a dense forest and suddenly you open up to a beach...its astonishing. It is small, not that soft sand, and full of coral stones on the shore. It is over crowded. Yes it has a small restaurant where they serve food and drinks and even few sun beds. But they are almost every time occupied. A great beach would be even greater if it was still not found by the crowd.

It is a bit of a hike to get to Jungle beach, but you want some seclusion from crowds at Unawatuna beach its an option, but told it can be busy at certain times.No real signs to point direction, double check if unsure. Take your water as the walk can get warm in the outdoors. Sheltered beach with pretty fish but again RUBBISH/TRASH.Please clean up your beaches for all living things. Sri Lankan beaches= sand, palm trees, warm water and whats that!...oh a plastic bag and a used diaper/nappy😝
Jungle Beach is one of a best place in Sri Lanka. Recommend to visit in early morning or afternoon. This small,  golden sandy beach added more beauty to her mother country.
Quite a walk to get to this one and walking back up the hill in 32c weather with insects biting you made it even less worth it. Go to unawatuna and give this coral littered tiny beach a miss.

It's quite a trek from Unawatana to Jungle Beach, about 30 minutes up and over a hill. Just before the last walk down, there is a small cafe, but there's nothing actually on the beach. The beach is pretty small, but the main reason for visiting is the water. Walk into the sea and towards the right and there is a reef about chest-deep where you can see all sorts of fish. It's like swimming in a tropical fish tank. Careful of the black spiky sea urchins, so don't stand on the reef!
Very small little cove beach on the other side of the peninsula to unawatuna. Quiet, great sea and sand, and a lovely wild walk up from the village.
this beach definitely worth it. It is nice little beach in middle of the jungle with nice entry to the see and nice clean water
Beautiful beach to escape to for the sunset. Bring some food and drink if you plan to stay for some time. Bar on beach but not open till Sun down. Picture postcard paradise

We walked from Unawatuna beach to jungle beach in our flip flops. It was hot, and a few places were a little rocky but it is definitely do-able. The beach is small, so not too much room to lounge out if it is busy. We arrived while many locals were enjoying the beach and playing around but still got to enjoy the beautiful waters without interruption. One vendor was selling coconuts but otherwise no food or drink available. Would recommend for an afternoon excursion.
I am sure on a good day this would be a nice beach, but it wasn't the day we visited. Sooo much rubbish on the beach, the water was murky and unpleasant. The walk down was nice though.
This would be a pretty nice beach, and you get a pretty nice hike to get there (or tuktuk), but what’s up with all the trash? That got me disappointed.

This beach is great! Nice soft sand, small waves, easy for swimming. The only downfall is how busy it is- I went on a Sunday and it was full with locals and tourists. Would definitely recommend going on a weekday. Also the walk/ mild hike there is beautiful!
Took a slightly roundabout path, but did not regret it. The rocky shores adjacent to the secluded beach are great for some quiet moments to watch waves crash into the large boulders.
All the reviews said this beach was good. We were really disappointed. The beach was dirty and the bar/restaurant expensive.
was an ok beach, not a whole lot to do and the waves/water is not spectacular. long walk down to get there too

spaiggia piccola e caotica in quanto frequentata sia dai local che dai turisti. molto sporca. viene anche suggerita come ottima per lo snorkelig ma in realtà cè poco da vedere. se avete poco tempo andate in altre spiaggie. small and chaotic because it is frequented by locals and tourists alike. very dirty. it is also suggested as good for snorkelig but in reality there is little to see. if you have little time go to other beaches.

Visited this beach via a tuk tuk for a morning with my family (3 adults, 4 children ages 7, 6, 3, & 1.)  First off, there are two beaches to jungle beach and we visited the beach which is closer to the temple, I think it is the smaller beach and is known for snorkeling.  As to the snorkeling, don't waste your time.  Very little fish to see, no coral, and poor water clarity (and I think we were on a good day for water clarity.)  Honestly, we brought our snorkel gear on our trip to Sri Lanka because of hopes to snorkel at jungle beach, if I go back, I won't bother carrying the stuff with me.  The beach itself was nice in the morning with a good amount of tourists, but not enough to be crowded.  Around about noon things started to get busy as many mothers were coming to the beach with their kids after school let out.  I didn't find any issue with this group of people other than the fact that there were a ton of them.  They just kept coming and coming and things were getting really crowded.  I am talking about going from roughly 50 - 60 tourists at the beach to probably 200+ after school crowd and growing.  So we decided to pack up and move on. If you want a somewhat secluded, calm beach with kind of clear water, then come by Jungle Beach in the morning and enjoy.  Other than that, I wouldn't bother coming to this beach.  Honestly, when back in Sri Lanka, I won't visit this beach again.  There are way better places than this.

The beach was perfect with golden Sands. However was a bit crowded as we visited on a weekend. The beach is surrounded by a small forest. A small Hill is to be climbed down to enter the beach. The beach offers some dine in options where you could even have a beer after a good splash in the waves.

We went there 3 times while we were staying in Galle. For the first time there were almost no one. The beach seemed very clean and quiet. We were happy that we found a good beach. So we went there another time omg there were sooo many locals and tourists. There is garbage everywhere and the beach is dirty. Well locals seem like they own this beach so they behave like this. Dogs are pooping to the water in front of you, drunk locals are looking like they are drowning and they just go and pee to the water and everyone can see. This place is disgusting. Take a bike and go somewhere else. We found so many nice beaches around so this one is not worth to go...

Generally a 350 Rupees tuk tuk ride from Unawatuna or Galle.  Two stop off points, one is 10 minute walk down to the beach, the second is 1k further along and takes you another area just around the bay.  Lovely beach with plenty of shade, if the sun gets too much.  Fish life is better than larger Unawatuna Beach.
Beautiful beach, to enter this you have to go through a jungle with trees and some insects in your way but when you get there its worth it, very nice beautiful beach with clear water
We took a tuk tuk to Japanese pagoda which was worth a visit then walked down to Jungle Beach. Nothing special here just a restaurant and 20 sunbed it would soon become packed.

We were told to come here and although it was raining we got a tuk tuk to visit without any intention of swimming. The tuk tuk dropped us at the top and we made our way down the jungle path until we reached the bay which was very calm, decided to have a paddle, the water was lovely and warm, locals were playing football on the small beach area. We ended up swimming in the rain, its a lovely bay even in the rain can only imagine what it's like in the sun. Worth a visit.
An ok place. Nice beach, warm wAter and a down hill walk- not for everyone. Food and drinks available.

We booked a snorkelling trip with the Taxi Service Office for two people $50:00, We were picked up at 08:30 as planned and taken by tuk tuk to unawatuna beach and then by two local guys to jungle beach, On arrival by boat we were offered to snorkel by jungle beach but the water is not clear and certainly not snorkelling water, many rocks also which are dangerous where my partner cut her toe, Would not recommend unawatuna for snorkelling,,,,,

Definitely worth a visit if in Unawatuna, as the beach is lovely and relatively secluded, without tons of restaurants like Unawatuna main beach. There is a small beach bar with drinks and some food choices and sun loungers. Getting there - follow signs from Unawantuna foot paths. You will be walking on a trail through the jungle until you get to a first beach (this is not Jungle Beach). From here, go to the end of this first beach and find the trail entry point to walk another 10 minutes to Jungle Beach. Total hike time is approximately 30-45 minutes. You will be walking on rocky trails - doable in flip flops if you're used to it; wear sneakers if you're not comfortable walking on uneven terrains. Recommended to go either in the morning or late afternoon to avoid mid-day heat.

I absolutely loved it here!  There is a short, tricky, (in flip flops) walk down, through jungle, from the road, to the beach.  This was fun though because the trees were filled with monkeys.  The beach was relatively quiet, which I also liked.  The sea was very calm here, unlike other places such as Bentota and Negumbo where it was rough.  The reason I loved it so much was that the snorkelling was amazing!!  It was like swimming in a huge aquarium. There were fishes of all colours and sizes, many I hadn't seen before and the absolute bonus was there were also turtles. This would have been a completely perfect experience, but there was quite a bit of rubbish around the edges of the beach, I think, probably washed up by the tide.  I would still fully recommend a visit or even two or three to this beach, especially if you enjoy snorkelling, it was the best beach I experience in the whole holiday. Drinks, beer etc. are available to buy.

A good place to visit. I recommend this place to any one. In Galle you can buy fish from fresh market but keep in mind they use 2 prize tag one is for locals and one in for foreigners. So before buy or use any thing ask few local about the actual pricing.
The way to this beach is not easy but it is worth it. We went there on Sunday and met mostly local people. The beach has spectacular views

A day in beach with delight, fun and observing with the nature of it's own make your self convienient to make a full of it by snorkeling, yachting, surfing and enlight the excitement. Cool & calm beach, made the delight of staying top of the rocks hanging around watching the excitement. Don't forget to bring your beach out fits, (Snorkeling, Slippers Etc...) water, snacks along the way and it's a fullfilling amaze for the family to hang around. Excellent place to be... Amazing!!! It's nature been bit out of order maybe it should develop the habitats of the coral reefs, be in a watchful eye for your belongings, be aware to take a little hike by walking. Please preserve the nature...!!! Dump the trash at the trash containers if not don't ever leave it behind... Make a moment for future generations too... Keep it tidy...!!! :::[Best Beach Experience]:::

We walked to jungle beach from Unawatuna beach took about 20-25 minutes. There are a few stops along the way that sell snacks and cold water. Jungle beach itself seemed to have more locals than tourists, which was nice. Plenty of shade, lovely beach.
Great beach with great views and few people but with reefs and rocks. Good place to snorkling but difficult to swim and enjoy the waters without get injured.

The walk to Jungle Beach is great! One can see monkeys, the Japanese Pagoda, stop by the side of the road and drink some coconut water, etc. The views are simply spectacular. Once at the beach, then things get a bit disappointing: trash everywhere, from condom wrappers to discarded water bottles and everything in between. This is a preferred spot for locals who come in large groups to party at the beach. The beach itself is nice enough but the view is dreadful: looking out from the beach into the horizon, one sees the entire port and industrial Galle complex in the near distance. The opposite of the idyllic images “jungle beach” conjures. I stayed about half an hour and walked back to Unawatuna beach with its wonderful never ending horizon to look at, not an industrial/port facility. There is a restaurant before one goes down to the beach which is nice and worth visiting. If you are looking for a walk, this is the place to go, if you are looking for a pristine, off the beaten path beach, THIS IS NOT that place. My advise is to stay in Unawatuna and beyond, the beaches are easily accessed and the views and spaces more relaxing and beautiful. Not sure why Jungle Beach has been built up so much in the tourist “must see” activities.

We walked to this beach several times starting in unatwatuna, and the walk was really nice. the beach itself is also nice and in a idyllic setting, but there is also quite some waste laying around and sometimes people come with boats, so that it might not be that quiet sometimes. Water was nice, didn't see so many fish though. For us the tour walking there, having a a swim, relax a bit and walking back as a whole was the real adventure. Recommend the trip! (there is just one restaurant and a few stops with coconuts and water on the way, the beach itself does not have anything to eat or drink, which suits the peacefullness of the place. just keep that in mind when packing your bag!)

This is a gorgeous beach in a beautiful setting. It is perfect for young kids as the sea is tranquil. It is also quite romantic with various shady places for young couples to be alone. I imagine the snorkeling is good too give the tranquillity and slow incline of the coast. I would rate this a five but for the fact that it was a bit dirty in the sea (I removed a bottle wrapper and a dirty cloth whilst my wife removed a bit of glass and placed in the bins). We both also managed to cut ourselves on the rocks in the sea but this was due to not taking care in the water. This isn't a place for folks with mobility issues unless they are coming by boat as the climb down from the road is a bit steep and rocky.

We saw the sign 'jungle beach' and thought it was worth exploring. It is a bit of a hike, up and down two hills, to get there, and that is the real interesting part as you pass trough a jungle-type of area. Once there, the first part of the beach is a bit congested (again with local boats) but the larger part, for which you have a pass a rocky area towards Galle/West, is more quiet. Great for swimming (rocky coast, clear water)

We were advised this beach a few times by our tuk-tuk driver. Remote and isolated indeed. Yet, the beach is located in the closed bay of Galle and is therefore unfortunately dirty... beach itself and most importantly water. So many other beaches are so great around... avoid this one.

Jungle beach is a great place to chill. Visited with friends in December. Trip to Mirissa was on Xmas day. Got to Jungle beach at around 9.30am and had the beach to ourself. It started getting crowded around 11am. Getting to location is a bit tough but that’s what is great about the place.
To isolated and if you have any walking problems can be difficult to reach unless you take boat trip.
We got the feeling that jungle beach would be a little paradise. Pretty disappointed I was. Small, dirty and indifferent. But the walk to it was nice
One of the most beautiful beaches in Sri Lanka :) almost a Maldives touch :))) very recommended once you’re in Unawatuna.

The beach itself is small, and nice enough, accessed by a very dicey path down through the greenery from the road but unfortunately tourists are animals and have made a real mess of it. Piles of garbage at the tree line make it very sad indeed, and no effort seems to be made to clean it up. Not sure it was really worth a trip.
It was so good that more than unawatuna beach we had more privacy here,not much crowded, its best for  teenagers and couples

One of the greatest and marvelous beach in the Sri Lanka wich situated in down-south,Sri Lanka. Very peaceful and attractive beach. There’s a very famous story stick with the Rumassala mountain next to the beach about Rama and king Rawana. This beach may have very peaceful and beautiful nature and please visitors have keep it up and clean the environment.

It is one of the best views in Sri Lanka in Unawatuna. Jungale beach is super blue view and blue water can be enjoyed by anyone. it is very green jungle the road to the beach which should be walk along.

The walk was great, the beach itself is not worth staying. Dont expect a hidden blue lagoon. There is a cocktailbar and quite a bit of people, locals and tourists. The place is polluted and lost quite a bit of its charm it must have had 10 years ago.

The beach is well looked after by the people that work there. They clean up any litter in the morning. It’s sad that there is litter that has to be cleaned up in the first place. Otherwise it’s a really beautiful beach and the sea is pretty calm. You can walk there from Unawatuna. A nice morning or afternoon excursion. I would recommend going early in the morning to avoid the busy times and on the weekends there is sometimes loud music which was a huge put off.

Great short walk from Unawatuna, save yourself for a 50rp coconut on the way back. Nice to be walking through a bushy area. The beach was very crowded by 10am, glad we chose to go early and everyone is jostling for shade. Worth snorkelling, saw some lovely fish. The rubbish is overwhelming,  as it is in a lot of Sri Lanka, please make sure you dont add to it and carry your rubbish including your cigarette butts out!

The calmest sea we visited, clean water we could see different types of fish swimming around us, its a very small beach and gets crowded at the weekend. their is a restaurant a short walk away. to walk from Unawatuna is a little hard with steep hills both up and down and very uneven rocky paths we loved it
Beach was nice but super busy. Doesn't seem worth traveling to this beach when busier than main unawatuna beach. View of peace pagoda and jungle area from beach is nice.

It's a shame about this beach as it ticks a lot of boxes. It's in an idyllic location cut off and surrounded by jungle, soft sand and lovely calm waters to swim in. Unfortunately it's way too busy, with rubbish everywhere and dirty water. This is due to it's popularity when we arrived it was so busy that we left after half an hour and went to Unawatuna.

Small beach close to Unawatuna. Took a tuk-tuk from hotel. Paid 500 each way and was dropped of right by the path down to the beach. Came around 9am and had beach almost to ourself. Do get busier, but did not feel crowded and one can snorkle.
This beach is supposed to be really special. The walk there is interesting though hard through the ‘jungle’. The beach however is nothing special.
We had a great afternoon at jungle BEACH, The water is very clear and you can do some snorkling alone the shore.
This beach should be wonderful but has a litter problem at the end. You need to go south or east away from the crowds

Ok beach, but so much overrated. It’s isolated yes - but that's about it. Filled with rubbish laying between the trees. I went snorkeling, but disappointed because a thin layer of sand covered rocks and corals and hardly no fish to see Choose Dalawella Beach instead. But You can see the pagoda in the same time..
I read about this beach good reviews  , but we were dissapointed. Watter were so dirty and muddy .we stayed there only one hour and go to another place

I had read lots of reviews saying that this beach was dirty and covered in litter but I found it perfectly clean! The walk down to the beach isn't difficult. It has a clear path and steps most of the way. There are no big waves so the water is perfect for swimming in. There are a few stalls on the road before walking down to the beach selling drinks and snacks. Here you will also find tuk tuks waiting for when you want to go home. On the beach itself there is a bar selling drinks and snacks. The scenery here is beautiful. You can walk from here up to the beautiful Japanese Peace Pagoda which I recommend going to for sunset.

My husband and I visited Jungle beach and had the best day. Little cozy beach where you can get fresh juice and milkshakes from the bar at the beach. Lots of locals and a good place for snorkeling as well.
Nice beach, mainly used by locals. no real facilities except for one very basic beach cafe & no sunbeds

This is a wonderful beach with moderate tide strength. Nice sand and clear water, also this place is good for calm peace lovers. There are two beach shacks, where you can eat food. Occasionally you can see some wedding photo shoot happening in this beach. The saddest fact I noticed is ocean&Beach pollution is tremendously hight in this beach... I have tried my best to pick up the trash.. Still people should think before they throw plastics in the sea. The beauty of the beach was spoiled due to plenty of trash. If you plan to go.. I would strongly recommend to contribute your share in cleaning this beach.

We went to Jungle beach and we’re pleasantly surprised.You have a long walk down through thin jungle to reach the beach but when you get there it is full of tourists relaxing with cocktails from a pop up bar that is there.There Still was pollution in the sea but less than other places in Sri Lankan.First and only time we got in the water in a 3 week period.Worth the visit

Nice walk through jungle to this small, simple beach with plenty of shadow. No chairs, no food, only some coconuts and softdrinks for sale. When we were there (2 days), there were also groups of Sri Lankan men, dancing, singing and drumming together. For some people a noise, for us a joy

We were staying in a hotel near Unawatuna beach and it was just over a 30 minute walk to Jungle beach. We walked along a track for 15 minutes before it became much more rugged and we had to climb up and down a rocky path. Before going down to the beach we visited the Peace Pagoda but remember to take your own refreshments as there is no cafe at the beach. The Jungle beach is in a small cove but because it was a Sunday when we were visited, it was very busy and we wished we had visited on a weekday. It is a nice beach to enjoy a swim as it is very protected and at the top of the cliff there was a nice cafe to enjoy a drink.
It is a nice beach ( small One ) located among the jungle ,it is quite beach with no deep water like other beaches

As it says the jungle meets the beach, the walk down is quite short and a Tuk tuk can take you most of the way. It involves a few rocks but manageable in flip flops and not only for the bravehearted and worth the views at the end. Facilities at the beach are limited but cold drinks/water/fresh fruit and snorkel masks available. The beach is smaller compared to nearby unwatuna but not as many people make the journey and trees provide good shade for those taking rest for the sun. Sea is generally calm and plenty of fish to see. Definitely worth a trip.
Nice nature. It is real similar to a jungle landscape. Also the monkeys are funny. The sand is very yellow and fine. But never in my not so short life I have seen so much rubbish on the beach!
This beach is good for a visit but not to stay longer. It doesnt have enough space also crowded on the day i went. most of them were locals.
Nice Beach , you have to walk down to the jungle first. But beware of the many rocks in the water. That was My mistake!
If you don’t mind flocks of Russian tourists, this is a great place to go to for a swim. Of course this could just be a matter of councidence.
It's a very small beach in the jungles. Not the best place for family, but must be visit with friends. Take about 10 minutes walking from pagoda

If you plan your trip to Galle, you must  visit this beach. It is 1.5Km journey from Galle-Matara -Hambanthota- Wellayawa road, Rumassala junction (Jungle Beach Junction).      Junction is just after passing the bridge near INSEE cement plant Galle. This road will lead to a top of the jungle beach where you have to step down through a dark jungle to reach this hidden beach.Best place to watch Sunset in Galle. A place where mountain steep and beach meets.
We should have taken notice of some previous reviews! This is a grotty little beach, backed by lots of rubbish. You have to walk down a rocky path to get to it, there are other, nicer places to go.
Although secluded, this beach was the busiest of all in Unawatuna. Probably since it is so small. There are better options.

i ve really looked forward to go to the jungle beach once in Sri Lanka ,but i found it too small,and poluted! garbage everywhere ! even if it was isolated we spent couple of minutes there and than left. one positive thing is the jungle path leading to it,we encountered monkeys and beautiful flora!

I love this beach because it is so small, hidden behind the trees and rocks and never crowded! There are a few cabanas that sell drinks and some food (not good food, stick to the basics). The beach has a few long chairs for you to relax and sun bathe. A 5 minute hike is required to see or even get to the beach... definitely worth it :)

We took a tuk tuk to this beautiful sounding beach and on arrival we weren’t disappointed.  Gorgeous sandy beach, a little cove and sea was clear and inviting.  We walked a little along the beach, past the sun beds and bar/restaurant.  Took some lovely photos and then we arrived at the dump site!  Loads of bottles, packets, plastic stuff - it was really sad to see as only down the road is a turtle sanctuary!  David Attenborough would not approve of the site we saw, too upsetting to actually take a picture.  I would recommend you visit as it is a gorgeous little cove, you just have to put the rubbish out of your mind.  Please Sri Lanka love your beautiful country and clean it up!

We went for A walk from Unawatuna beach to Jungle Beach. The Nice Little beach had A Little snack bar. The water was extremely clear. I recommend this beach. On your way You can buy Coconut water and pinapples along the Road😃👍🏼🇱🇰

I really enjoyed the walk up the hills and through the village and jungle to the beach. The beach was a little crowded but the water was beautiful. Head to the Japanese Peace Pagoda too as it's at the top of the hill.
Great beach for kids and very beautiful ! Only road is among jungle . But if u like the nature u will like it

These are very close together and can be done on the same Tuk Tuk journey from Unawatuna. The driver stayed with us at the JPP then dropped us off at Jungle Beach for 3 hours before returning. Relatively small beach down a steep path with just one vendor, backed by dense trees. Not as good as the main Unawatuna beach.

We went to Jungle beach by boat. Beach is small. In that day were crowded. For snorkelling is fine, but not much of corals, more of rocks. we were in January the wave were not very high and water temperature was perfect.

We went here twice. Its a small beach, few turists and some locals. No food or other facilities, only a guy selling juice and cocktails, but still nice. Also you can do some snorkeling if you bring your own gear! You walk through "the jungle" to get here and may see monkeys, monitor Lizards, peacocks and maybe other animals on your hike.
Well what can I say this place is spectacular, the beach is absolutely beautiful, the cocktail bar serves wonderful drinks and if your into snorkelling it’s a great location.

Took a 500 LKR Tuk Tuk from Unawatuna to jungle beach, and spent a lovely afternoon there (there are plenty of Tuk Tuks waiting there to take people back, no need to arrange a round trip).  The walk down from the road is a mix of rocky stairs and dirt. We went on a Saturday, and the beach was packed with tourists and locals, but there was a patch of sand for everyone.

Our friends had read and heard mixed reviews of this beach. We actually quite enjoyed it! The water was clear and lovely. We got a tuk tuk there and had a great time walking back to unawatuna beach. Would recommend visiting this beach. Perhaps don't bother snorkelling as there is not much to see.

We explored by walking the area up to jungle beach. It was a cloudy day but the beach was surrounded by nice trees and flowers and very quiet. Around it seems to be larger villa resort but still I appreciated that the beach was not crowded. There a small rotti / juice shop on the beach. Nice beach if you want less waves and less people around.
Worth going to the Jungle Beach - fantastic scenery, great water quality and lovely view.  Absolute must - if you are nearby.

You have to take a short downhill trek through the jungle to get to this beach, which was very enjoyable. The beach itself is nice to look at, but the water is not great for swimming. There are dead corals everywhere and chunks of rock you can injure yourself on. The water is muddy because a river empties into the ocean nearby.

We walked from Unawatuna to the Junglebeach, a very nice but not very easy walk. The beach is beautiful, nice sand, clear water with beautiful fishes (snorkling). Unfortunatly it is very crowded, even visited by groups! You can also reach the beach by car now. So don't expect an idyllic quiet beach. Unfortunately there is a lot of junk (plastic bottles) behind the beach and in the jungle. We did't find any garbage cans. We think in a few years, there is not much left of this beach

This was a stunning little beach! It had a great cocktail bar and also a small place to eat which I didn’t try but it was great for snorkelling and the monkeys provided some great entertainment going about their business! It was great to sit back and relax and take in the beautiful surroundings!
Small beach with a lot of waste, boats and people - no need to go there. There are better beaches in Sri Lanka. Disappointing

The owner of our place in Galle recommended we visit Jungle Beach early before the crowds, we got there at 08:30 and had to ourselves for about 30 mins before snorkel boats arrived and other people from down the track. We drove ourselves and parked by the shop for 100, we then walked down the track to the beach - you could take a tuk tuk all the way. Snorkelling just off the beach was good, hence the boats, and the sand is lovely - a sweet little beach between Unawatuna and Galle

The only problem is that we need to hire  a tuk tuk to go down the hill about 1km to get to the beach, but the beach itself is very nice with crystal clear water. The beach is bit crowded with limited parking area.

Compared to the beach in unawatuna this one was heavily overcrowded. People said it would be much more chilled out than the other beaches, but this was not the case. The beach was clean and we could not see any trash in the water. The hike was nice and not strenous for young people. I’d advise to check it out, but not get your hopes up high.

Perfect beach with a great tropical feeling. Not to crowded when w e were there. Sell water and beverages at the beach. Lion bear 500rupies, cola 300. Was offered tuktuk there for 200rupies from "no name resort". When you go back the first tuktuk are a bit sneaky and demands 600rupies for the return. We walk towards the pagoda(right turn) about 300m and got a return for 300rupies. Recommend snorkeling. Lots of fish and octopus. The walk there trough the jungle trail is quite warm and exhausting, you literary walk trough the jungle and there are steep climbs and descends. The walk is not for olds and probably not perfect for families. If i went there again  it would definitely be tuktuk.
Different beach than Unawatuna. It is less crowdy, with a view on a rock cliff. Worth visiting at least once. Buy a coconut when going back to Unawatuna!

This beach is a little bit of a walk but you can get a tuk tuk to get there. I personally loved resting under palms and swimming in this calm bay. It’s quite popular so better go there in the morning to avoid crowds.

Seems to be a hidden germ, but it is not really that; quite a few people (local & tourists) use this place which has a nice atmosphere, but it is crowded and there are far better alternatives further East along the coast if you want more privacy.

The beach and area are beautiful. I think when you catch the beach at a quiet moment it will be amazing. When we visit jungle beach on poya day it was very crowded and lots of locals were getting drunk and partied at the beach.

My favorite spot during our short trip of 4 days in Sri Lanka. The beach and the surroundings are really amazing and worth visiting! You can reach from Unawatuna beach road with Tuk Tuk for 350-400 rupieh. Then you walk down through the bushes to reach to the beach, which is an experience by itself! The sea is not wavy so it is very good for a swim. There is one local bar offering drinks and some food for good rates.

You need to walk down the hill about 1km to get to the beach, but the beach itself is very nice with shallow water. The only downside is that it is a bit too crowded. There is only limited parking space on the roadsides, but there are private parking spaces - although their charges are somewhat unreasonable.
A nice walk through the jungle ruined by the beach which is very polluted and full of stacked up rubbish . Swimming is also difficult with coral and rocks underfoot . Don’t get what the fuss is about
Nice but a bit crowded beach, the view over Galle is not super nice but the hike was kind of fun. Visit the temple nearby as well

Jungle beach was a disappointment.  Walk to beach enjoyable, shaded by the trees, while the monkeys play. Steep hill with a poor footpath. Beach was very narrow, don’t really think you can say it has a restaurant, I certainly wouldn’t of eaten there. Sea polluted with plastic. Sold to us as a good place to snorkel with no waves, we never saw one fish only litter.

The trek to the beach was fairly enjoyable but this was in no way a secret. The beach was heaving and there was rubbish everywhere. Snorkelling trips were regular but all the coral has died in the area so there is nothing to see in the water.

I visited Jungle Beach on two occasions - one walking from Unawatuna through the "jungle" and another time via tuk tuk. The walk from Unawatuna was awesome through the bush and added to the specialness of arriving at the beach. This would not be suited for anyone with difficulty walking due to the stairs and uneven surfaces. If you do this walk it is doable in flip flops. The trip by tuk tuk was quick. There are two beaches - accessible to each other across some rocks. Well worth visiting both. The beach is lovely and less people than on the beaches at Unawatuna. Be careful when you enter the water as there are many rocks in areas which are not clearly visible until you step onto them. Look for where others are swimming and go to those areas. Lovely beach with no wind. Must visit.

This beach had ace reviews so it was high on my list. Firstly it's not for people who aren't particularly mobile as you have to walk down a steep slope/hillside to get there. The water had plastic in it so not the cleanest beach or water. There are hidden rocks/coral along much of it. Swim where there are people, if there is a section with no one there, prob due to hidden rocks under the water. There are much nicer beaches than here.
the beach like a out door pool. really nice. also we have try snorkeling. worth money. Rs.1500 for locals.
Went in the afternoon... Crowded, a lot of rubbish on the sand. Would be a nice spot if they cleaned it up. Nice walk down through the jungle. Can walk to it from Unawatuna

We got there at 8am and were first on the beach to get our pick of sun loungers. Sun rises from behind beach, and is on the beach from about 9. It’s a small beach but nice to walk along. Quite a bit of litter washing up & quite a few rocks in the water. Still nice to see and spend a few hours.
Water was filled with garbage at our visit. Otherwise a very beautiful beach. The access is a bit of a hike.

The walk through the woods is quiet fun and to add to that the Beautiful jingle beach!! The water was a bit rough so we couldn't snorkel or do any water activities but  a great place to just lay down on the beach bed and enjoy the view :)

The beach could be beautiful with nice sand and green hills leading down to it. But both the water and the beach is full of plastic garbage. When you snorkel it is easier to spot a coke can than a fish. When you swim a bit further out you can see quite a lot of fish though.
Small beach without tourists or almost. Guaranteed immersion. This beach is worth, you have to walk a little, hence its name.

We walked there today and it was really busy! I wouldn’t say that’s there much charm or appeal about either of the bays of  Jungle Beach as they’re both surrounded by rubbish, the sea is quite murky and there’s a restaurant which has a monopoly so they charge a lot for food. The path between the two beaches was pretty waterlogged, with a thick smelly mud. We both almost lost a flip flop to it and ended up with black mud up our legs and clothes. Grim.

The hike to the beach is lovely. We saw leguaans, butterflies and snakes. However, the beach itself is nothing special. It’s secluded but not that nice. Also, the beach faces the city of Galle with its industrial buildings and hotels, which isn’t a very pretty view. It is worth going there on a hike, but I would recommend the nearby Unawatuna beach for sunbathing etc.
Nothing special. I've seen much better beaches. Pros: sand, secluded place. Cons: far away, no sunbeds, a lot of plastic trash around.
Good spot for snorkelling (we saw many fish but the best was the cuttle fish). Lots of monkeys in the trees on the beach and iguanas as well.

I went to the jungle beach on a snorkeling trip. I'm not sure whether it was due to a recent storm, but visibility wasn't that great...and there was a lot of rubbish in the water. A nice enough stretch of beach for an afternoons sun worshipping.
Nice walk down the the beach but an anticlimax when you reach it. Unfortunately it’s littered with plastic bottles otherwise it would be beautiful.
Lovely walk, quite beach, surrounded by wildlife, monkeys and large lizards, snorkelling and chilling
We went here for snorkling, the beach was really polluted and there were a lot of people. Not recommended for relaxation. Ok for snorkling.
Visited here for the day, it could be amazing but unfortunately the sea is full of rubbish (I guess due to the bay) so all pretty disgusting. Ended up back at Unawatuna where there is no rubbish
The inclusion of this beach in Lonely Planet means lots of folks know about it, but that does make it less lovely. You have to sort of hike down to it and the beach feels very secluded. Great.

We read some mixed reviews about this beach. We tried anyway, and even though our expectations were not very high, we still got a bit disappointed. You will find a steep slope with some man made steps, not in the best of conditions, but still easy to access the beach. There was a lot of garbage in the path of "jungle". The beach was also super dirty, and you can see that this garbage comes from the sea, with the tide bringing bottles, plastics and other stuff. The sand is mostly coral rock, so, not very comfortable. Small in sand area, with many local small boats, and a few "bars" it's hard to find a place to put your towel. I would recommend to skip this one.
I'm sure this was a secluded tranquil beach about 15 years ago. It was packed when we got there with very little beach to sit on. Pretty but not quite as peaceful as we'd hoped!
Not the best beach. Small, trash in water and on beach and if you are unlucky (as we are) there are groups of screaming local youngsters playing loud music. Beach in Unawatuna is better.
Yes it's nice but it was very filthy with rubbish and it's very small. Not my favourite place to visit in Sri Lanka that's for sure.
I walked from the peace pagoda to the jungle beach which was a nice 10-15min walk but the beach itself is dirty and was very full in the afternoon.

Pros: - Clean beach - Not too crowded - Calm sea - Access to White Jungle Beach among the rocks / path (Personally I preferred Jungle Beach) Cons: - Be aware 30min walk through the wilderness (unless getting a Tuc-Tuc to a local Hotel)

Just lovely! Fairly quiet, not too touristy, right in the middle of a jungle with real monkies;) You'll be able to get all refreshments and fruits. Mind you the path down to the beach is still a bit wild, true Sri Lankan experience!

A short walk through the jungle if you go by tuk-tuk. Otherwise a bit longer from the main road. There are two beaches with some rocks in between. You have to scramble over the rocks to go between them. There are quite some fish just in front of these rocks so very nice snorkeling straight from the beach. There are some guys with boats to take you further out, but I don’t know what they charge or if it is worth it to go further out. Gets busier after 11:00. When we were there, both beaches were free of rubbish.

Nice place to relax. The beach strip isn't too long but it's long enough and not many people are aware of the place. There is a little bar with seats for a refreshment at normal pricing. If you don't mind taking the short hike down the road through the woods, def a nice place to relax and have a fresh juice.
Small Beach used by locals. Food available and Beer. Prices resonable. Water calm and warm. 500r from town with Tuc Tuc. Spent a nice afternoon there away from the hustle and bustle of City.

We walked from Unawatuna - takes about 30 minutes through a nice jungle track. Unfortunately the beach itself is strewn with rubbish - in the jungle, on the sand and in the water. Ruins an otherwise nice, calm spot to swim.

We heard this was an amazing beach but were sadly disappointed. Way overcrowded with gangs of teenage boys banging on their drums. Rubbish everywhere and the water looked brown. Beach hut way overpriced and staff extremely rude. Go to another beach and save yourself the time!
Lovely days spent in this hidden treasure! Perfect for young kids and snorkeling. Good way to spend the day and maybe go to the next beach on for the late afternoon surfing!
Can hike to this beach through a trail in the jungle in about 20-30 minutes from the beach near Unawatuna. Saw some monkeys swinging through the trees. Not totally secluded but still special.

The guys who managed to put up a beach hut acts as if he owns the beach. He make sure he exploits every opportunity to the maximum. The outrageous amounts he charges cannot be justified by the way he maintains the beach area. I know its not his duty, But he could at least do something about the huge pile of garbage that is collecting at the beach. I'm sure he is a major contributor to it.

Tiny strip of sand between a steep jungle covered slope and a dirty sea. Took a glass bottom boat and the bay, saw plenty of plastic bags and bottles float passed but only about three fish. Really wouldn't bother!

You get here by walking downhill a few hundred meters on a path through the jungle. Actually 2 beaches. Some parts has a lot of trash and nobody cleans. Visited during October and before the weather settled. Less waves here than on Unawatuna and other beaches further east. Tip: we visited on a weekend, and the beach was very crowded. In addition a large group of young boys spent the day there getting drunk. Probably not a problem unless you travel with kids or are looking for a quiet getaway
We went early in the morning and no one was there. It was a perfect time for a swim. The walk was beautiful through the forest where we came across monkeys and lovely colourful birds.

It is unusual to go to the beach through a jungle, but it is good experience. The sand is pleasant for feet, the sunset is great as well, yet once we were in the water, there are rests of shells etc. and I scratched myself to blood when a wave hit me down.. therefore 4/5.. the waves are generally bigger in this part of Sri Lanka, so it is nice to watch, but not so great to swim in.. in the afternoon.. the best option is to come in the morning:)

No longer a hidden location, Nice beach for a swim. Foreigners and locals as well. May be 90% locals, lot of noise coming from shouting, drumming, dancing and just having fun. All seem to get alone fine. Bit of trash thrown around but surprised not too much. There are two beaches – we were at the far end one. Few parking spots available. Was getting busier as we left around 11 AM..
Breath taking experience! Very pristine beach with soft sand and clear water. The    walk to get here maybe tiresome and little scary especially in the evening but definitely worth the trouble.

We were directed to this place by a friend. The tuk tuk driver knew where to take us and directed us to a path that leads down to the beach. We managed to negotiate the off beaten path in flip flops but it is uneven in places so do take care. This beach was beautiful once at the bottom, not overcrowded and seemed to be a favourite among the locals. There is a small cafe type bar on the beach serving drinks and light bites. The sea is calm enough to swim around here, walking to the left over the rocks you'll get to another cove which seems a lot cleaner than the first.
